p.verse: 1The vision concerning Judah and Jerusalem that Isaiah son of Amoz saw during the reigns of Kings Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah of Judah.

poem.verse: 2Listen, heavens, and pay attention, earth,

poetryblock.poem: for the Lord has spoken:
‘I have raised children and brought them up,
but they have rebelled against me.

poem.verse: 3The ox knows its owner,

poetryblock.poem: and the donkey its master’s feeding trough,
but Israel does not know;
my people do not understand.’

poem.verse: 4Oh sinful nation,

poetryblock.poem: people weighed down with iniquity,
brood of evildoers,
depraved children!
They have abandoned the Lord;
they have despised the Holy One of Israel;
they have turned their backs on him.

poem.verse: 5Why do you want more beatings?

poetryblock.poem: Why do you keep on rebelling?
The whole head is hurt,
and the whole heart is sick.

poem.verse: 6From the sole of the foot even to the head,

poetryblock.poem: no spot is uninjured –
wounds, welts, and festering sores
not cleansed, bandaged,
or soothed with oil.

poem.verse: 7Your land is desolate,

poetryblock.poem: your cities burned down;
foreigners devour your fields
right in front of you –
a desolation, like a place demolished by foreigners.

poem.verse: 8Daughter Zion is abandoned

poetryblock.poem: like a shelter in a vineyard,
like a shack in a cucumber field,
like a besieged city.

poem.verse: 9If the Lord of Armies

poetryblock.poem: had not left us a few survivors,
we would be like Sodom,
we would resemble Gomorrah.

poem.verse: 10Hear the word of the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: you rulers of Sodom!
Listen to the instruction of our God,
you people of Gomorrah!

poem.verse: 11‘What are all your sacrifices to me? ’

poetryblock.poem: asks the Lord.
‘I have had enough of burnt offerings and rams
and the fat of well-fed cattle;
I have no desire for the blood of bulls,
lambs, or male goats.

poem.verse: 12When you come to appear before me,

poetryblock.poem: who requires this from you –
this trampling of my courts?

poem.verse: 13Stop bringing useless offerings.

poetryblock.poem: Your incense is detestable to me.
New Moons and Sabbaths,
and the calling of solemn assemblies –
I cannot stand iniquity with a festival.

poem.verse: 14I hate your New Moons and prescribed festivals.

poetryblock.poem: They have become a burden to me;
I am tired of putting up with them.

poem.verse: 15When you spread out your hands in prayer,

poetryblock.poem: I will refuse to look at you;
even if you offer countless prayers,
I will not listen.
Your hands are covered with blood.

poem.verse: 16‘Wash yourselves. Cleanse yourselves.

poetryblock.poem: Remove your evil deeds from my sight.
Stop doing evil.

poem.verse: 17Learn to do what is good.

poetryblock.poem: Pursue justice.
Correct the oppressor.
Defend the rights of the fatherless.
Plead the widow’s cause.

poem.verse: 18‘Come, let’s settle this,’

poetryblock.poem: says the Lord.
‘Though your sins are scarlet,
they will be as white as snow;
though they are crimson red,
they will be like wool.

poem.verse: 19If you are willing and obedient,

poetryblock.poem: you will eat the good things of the land.

poem.verse: 20But if you refuse and rebel,

poetryblock.poem: you will be devoured by the sword.’
For the mouth of the Lord has spoken.

poem.verse: 21The faithful town –

poetryblock.poem: what an adulteress she has become!
She was once full of justice.
Righteousness once dwelt in her,
but now, murderers!

poem.verse: 22Your silver has become dross to be discarded,

poetryblock.poem: your beer is diluted with water.

poem.verse: 23Your rulers are rebels,

poetryblock.poem: friends of thieves.
They all love graft
and chase after bribes.
They do not defend the rights of the fatherless,
and the widow’s case never comes before them.

poem.verse: 24Therefore the Lord God of Armies,

poetryblock.poem: the Mighty One of Israel, declares:
‘Ah, I will get even with my foes;
I will take revenge against my enemies.

poem.verse: 25I will turn my hand against you

poetryblock.poem: and will burn away your dross completely;
I will remove all your impurities.

poem.verse: 26I will restore your judges to what they were at first,

poetryblock.poem: and your advisers to what they were at the start.
Afterwards you will be called the Righteous City,
a Faithful Town.’

poem.verse: 27Zion will be redeemed by justice,

poetryblock.poem: those who repent, by righteousness.

poem.verse: 28At the same time both rebels and sinners will be broken,

poetryblock.poem: and those who abandon the Lord will perish.

poem.verse: 29Indeed, they will be ashamed of the sacred trees

poetryblock.poem: you desired,
and you will be embarrassed because of the garden shrines
you have chosen.

poem.verse: 30For you will become like an oak

poetryblock.poem: whose leaves are withered,
and like a garden without water.

poem.verse: 31The strong one will become tinder,

poetryblock.poem: and his work a spark;
both will burn together,
with no one to extinguish the flames.

p.verse: 1The vision that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:

poem.verse: 2In the last days

poetryblock.poem: the mountain of the Lord’s house will be established
at the top of the mountains
and will be raised above the hills.
All nations will stream to it,

poem.verse: 3and many peoples will come and say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Come, let’s go up to the mountain of the Lord,
to the house of the God of Jacob.
He will teach us about his ways
so that we may walk in his paths.’
For instruction will go out of Zion
and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 4He will settle disputes among the nations

poetryblock.poem: and provide arbitration for many peoples.
They will beat their swords into ploughs
and their spears into pruning knives.
Nation will not take up the sword against nation,
and they will never again train for war.

poem.verse: 5House of Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: come and let’s walk in the Lord’s light.

poem.verse: 6For you have abandoned your people,

poetryblock.poem: the house of Jacob,
because they are full of divination from the East
and of fortune-tellers like the Philistines.
They are in league with foreigners.

poem.verse: 7Their land is full of silver and gold,

poetryblock.poem: and there is no limit to their treasures;
their land is full of horses,
and there is no limit to their chariots.

poem.verse: 8Their land is full of worthless idols;

poetryblock.poem: they worship the work of their hands,
what their fingers have made.

poem.verse: 9So humanity is brought low,

poetryblock.poem: and each person is humbled.
Do not forgive them!

poem.verse: 10Go into the rocks

poetryblock.poem: and hide in the dust
from the terror of the Lord
and from his majestic splendour.

poem.verse: 11The pride of mankind will be humbled,

poetryblock.poem: and human loftiness will be brought low;
the Lord alone will be exalted on that day.

poem.verse: 12For a day belonging to the Lord of Armies is coming

poetryblock.poem: against all that is proud and lofty,
against all that is lifted up ​– ​it will be humbled –

poem.verse: 13against all the cedars of Lebanon,

poetryblock.poem: lofty and lifted up,
against all the oaks of Bashan,

poem.verse: 14against all the high mountains,

poetryblock.poem: against all the lofty hills,

poem.verse: 15against every high tower,

poetryblock.poem: against every fortified wall,

poem.verse: 16against every ship of Tarshish,

poetryblock.poem: and against every splendid sea vessel.

poem.verse: 17The pride of mankind will be brought low,

poetryblock.poem: and human loftiness will be humbled;
the Lord alone will be exalted on that day.

poem.verse: 18The worthless idols will vanish completely.
19People will go into caves in the rocks

poetryblock.poem: and holes in the ground,
away from the terror of the Lord
and from his majestic splendour,
when he rises to terrify the earth.

poem.verse: 20On that day people will throw

poetryblock.poem: their worthless idols of silver and gold,
which they made to worship,
to the moles and the bats.

poem.verse: 21They will go into the caves of the rocks

poetryblock.poem: and the crevices in the cliffs,
away from the terror of the Lord
and from his majestic splendour,
when he rises to terrify the earth.

poem.verse: 22Put no more trust in a mere human,

poetryblock.poem: who has only the breath in his nostrils.
What is he really worth?

poem.verse: 1Note this: The Lord God of Armies

poetryblock.poem: is about to remove from Jerusalem and from Judah
every kind of security:
the entire supply of bread and water,

poem.verse: 2heroes and warriors,

poetryblock.poem: judges and prophets,
fortune-tellers and elders,

poem.verse: 3commanders of fifty and dignitaries,

poetryblock.poem: counsellors, cunning magicians, and necromancers.

poem.verse: 4‘I will make youths their leaders,

poetryblock.poem: and unstable rulers will govern them.’

poem.verse: 5The people will oppress one another,

poetryblock.poem: man against man, neighbour against neighbour;
the young will act arrogantly towards the old,
and the worthless towards the honourable.

poem.verse: 6A man will even seize his brother

poetryblock.poem: in his father’s house, saying,
‘You have a cloak ​– ​you be our leader!
This heap of rubble will be under your control.’

poem.verse: 7On that day he will cry out, saying,

poetryblock.poem: ‘I’m not a healer.
I don’t even have food or clothing in my house.
Don’t make me the leader of the people! ’

poem.verse: 8For Jerusalem has stumbled

poetryblock.poem: and Judah has fallen
because they have spoken and acted against the Lord,
defying his glorious presence.

poem.verse: 9The look on their faces testifies against them,

poetryblock.poem: and like Sodom, they flaunt their sin;
they do not conceal it.
Woe to them,
for they have brought disaster on themselves.

poem.verse: 10Tell the righteous that it will go well for them,

poetryblock.poem: for they will eat the fruit of their labour.

poem.verse: 11Woe to the wicked ​– ​it will go badly for them,

poetryblock.poem: for what they have done will be done to them.

poem.verse: 12Youths oppress my people,

poetryblock.poem: and women rule over them.
My people, your leaders mislead you;
they confuse the direction of your paths.

poem.verse: 13The Lord rises to argue the case

poetryblock.poem: and stands to judge the people.

poem.verse: 14The Lord brings this charge

poetryblock.poem: against the elders and leaders of his people:
‘You have devastated the vineyard.
The plunder from the poor is in your houses.

poem.verse: 15Why do you crush my people

poetryblock.poem: and grind the faces of the poor? ’
This is the declaration
of the Lord God of Armies.

p.verse: 16The Lord also says:

poetryblock.poem: Because the daughters of Zion are haughty,
walking with heads held high
and seductive eyes,
prancing along,
jingling their ankle bracelets,

poem.verse: 17the Lord will put scabs on the heads

poetryblock.poem: of the daughters of Zion,
and the Lord will shave their foreheads bare.

p.verse: 18On that day the Lord will strip their finery: ankle bracelets, headbands, crescents,
19pendants, bracelets, veils,
20headdresses, ankle jewellery, sashes, perfume bottles, amulets,
21signet rings, nose rings,
22festive robes, capes, cloaks, purses,
23garments, linen clothes, turbans, and shawls.

poem.verse: 24Instead of perfume there will be a stench;

poetryblock.poem: instead of a belt, a rope;
instead of beautifully styled hair, baldness;
instead of fine clothes, sackcloth;
instead of beauty, branding.

poem.verse: 25Your men will fall by the sword,

poetryblock.poem: your warriors in battle.

poem.verse: 26Then her gates will lament and mourn;

poetryblock.poem: deserted, she will sit on the ground.

poem.verse: 1On that day seven women

poetryblock.poem: will seize one man, saying,
‘We will eat our own bread
and provide our own clothing.
Just let us bear your name.
Take away our disgrace.’

p.verse: 2On that day the Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land will be the pride and glory of Israel’s survivors.
3Whoever remains in Zion and whoever is left in Jerusalem will be called holy ​– ​all in Jerusalem written in the book of life ​– ​
4when the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and cleansed the bloodguilt from the heart of Jerusalem by a spirit of judgement and a spirit of burning.
5Then the Lord will create a cloud of smoke by day and a glowing flame of fire by night over the entire site of Mount Zion and over its assemblies. For there will be a canopy over all the glory,
6and there will be a shelter for shade from heat by day and a refuge and shelter from storm and rain.

poem.verse: 1I will sing about the one I love,

poetryblock.poem: a song about my loved one’s vineyard:
The one I love had a vineyard
on a very fertile hill.

poem.verse: 2He broke up the soil, cleared it of stones,

poetryblock.poem: and planted it with the finest vines.
He built a tower in the middle of it
and even dug out a winepress there.
He expected it to yield good grapes,
but it yielded worthless grapes.

poem.verse: 3So now, residents of Jerusalem

poetryblock.poem: and men of Judah,
please judge between me
and my vineyard.

poem.verse: 4What more could I have done for my vineyard

poetryblock.poem: than I did?
Why, when I expected a yield of good grapes,
did it yield worthless grapes?

poem.verse: 5Now I will tell you

poetryblock.poem: what I am about to do to my vineyard:
I will remove its hedge,
and it will be consumed;
I will tear down its wall,
and it will be trampled.

poem.verse: 6I will make it a wasteland.

poetryblock.poem: It will not be pruned or weeded;
thorns and briars will grow up.
I will also give orders to the clouds
that rain should not fall on it.

poem.verse: 7For the vineyard of the Lord of Armies

poetryblock.poem: is the house of Israel,
and the men of Judah,
the plant he delighted in.
He expected justice
but saw injustice;
he expected righteousness
but heard cries of despair.

poem.verse: 8Woe to those who add house to house

poetryblock.poem: and join field to field
until there is no more room
and you alone are left in the land.

p.verse: 9I heard the Lord of Armies say:

poetryblock.poem: Indeed, many houses will become desolate,
grand and lovely ones without inhabitants.

poem.verse: 10For a ten-acre vineyard will yield

poetryblock.poem: only 22 litres of wine,
and 220 litres of seed will yield
only 22 litres of grain.

poem.verse: 11Woe to those who rise early in the morning

poetryblock.poem: in pursuit of beer,
who linger into the evening,
inflamed by wine.

poem.verse: 12At their feasts they have lyre, harp,

poetryblock.poem: tambourine, flute, and wine.
They do not perceive the Lord’s actions,
and they do not see the work of his hands.

poem.verse: 13Therefore my people will go into exile

poetryblock.poem: because they lack knowledge;
her dignitaries are starving,
and her masses are parched with thirst.

poem.verse: 14Therefore Sheol enlarges its throat

poetryblock.poem: and opens wide its enormous jaws,
and down go Zion’s dignitaries, her masses,
her crowds, and those who celebrate in her!

poem.verse: 15Humanity is brought low, each person is humbled,

poetryblock.poem: and haughty eyes are humbled.

poem.verse: 16But the Lord of Armies is exalted by his justice,

poetryblock.poem: and the holy God demonstrates his holiness through his righteousness.

poem.verse: 17Lambs will graze

poetryblock.poem: as if in their own pastures,
and resident foreigners will eat
among the ruins of the rich.

poem.verse: 18Woe to those who drag iniquity

poetryblock.poem: with cords of deceit
and pull sin along with cart ropes,

poem.verse: 19to those who say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Let him hurry up and do his work quickly
so that we can see it!
Let the plan of the Holy One of Israel take place
so that we can know it! ’

poem.verse: 20Woe to those who call evil good

poetryblock.poem: and good evil,
who substitute darkness for light
and light for darkness,
who substitute bitter for sweet
and sweet for bitter.

poem.verse: 21Woe to those who consider themselves wise

poetryblock.poem: and judge themselves clever.

poem.verse: 22Woe to those who are heroes at drinking wine,

poetryblock.poem: who are champions at pouring beer,

poem.verse: 23who acquit the guilty for a bribe

poetryblock.poem: and deprive the innocent of justice.

poem.verse: 24Therefore, as a tongue of fire consumes straw

poetryblock.poem: and as dry grass shrivels in the flame,
so their roots will become like something rotten
and their blossoms will blow away like dust,
for they have rejected
the instruction of the Lord of Armies,
and they have despised
the word of the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 25Therefore the Lord’s anger burned against his people.

poetryblock.poem: He raised his hand against them and struck them;
the mountains quaked,
and their corpses were like rubbish in the streets.
In all this, his anger has not turned away,
and his hand is still raised to strike.

poem.verse: 26He raises a signal flag for the distant nations

poetryblock.poem: and whistles for them from the ends of the earth.
Look ​– ​how quickly and swiftly they come!

poem.verse: 27None of them grows weary or stumbles;

poetryblock.poem: no one slumbers or sleeps.
No belt is loose
and no sandal strap broken.

poem.verse: 28Their arrows are sharpened,

poetryblock.poem: and all their bows strung.
Their horses’ hooves are like flint;
their chariot wheels are like a whirlwind.

poem.verse: 29Their roaring is like a lion’s;

poetryblock.poem: they roar like young lions;
they growl and seize their prey
and carry it off,
and no one can rescue it.

poem.verse: 30On that day they will roar over it,

poetryblock.poem: like the roaring of the sea.
When one looks at the land,
there will be darkness and distress;
light will be obscured by clouds.

p.verse: 1In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord seated on a high and lofty throne, and the hem of his robe filled the temple.
2Seraphim were standing above him; they each had six wings: with two they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they flew.
3And one called to another:

poetryblock.poem: Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of Armies;
his glory fills the whole earth.

p.verse: 4The foundations of the doorways shook at the sound of their voices, and the temple was filled with smoke.
5Then I said:

poetryblock.poem: Woe is me, for I am ruined,
because I am a man of unclean lips
and live among a people of unclean lips,
and because my eyes have seen the King,
the Lord of Armies.

p.verse: 6Then one of the seraphim flew to me, and in his hand was a glowing coal that he had taken from the altar with tongs.
7He touched my mouth with it and said:

poetryblock.poem: Now that this has touched your lips,
your iniquity is removed
and your sin is atoned for.

p.verse: 8Then I heard the voice of the Lord asking:

poetryblock.poem: Whom shall I send?
Who will go for us?
Here I am. Send me.

p.verse: 9And he replied:

poetryblock.poem: Go! Say to these people:
Keep listening, but do not understand;
keep looking, but do not perceive.

poem.verse: 10Make the minds of these people dull;

poetryblock.poem: deafen their ears and blind their eyes;
otherwise they might see with their eyes
and hear with their ears,
understand with their minds,
turn back, and be healed.

p.verse: 11Then I said, ‘Until when, Lord? ’ And he replied:

poetryblock.poem: Until cities lie in ruins without inhabitants,
houses are without people,
the land is ruined and desolate,

poem.verse: 12and the Lord drives the people far away,

poetryblock.poem: leaving great emptiness in the land.

poem.verse: 13Though a tenth will remain in the land,

poetryblock.poem: it will be burned again.
Like the terebinth or the oak
that leaves a stump when felled,
the holy seed is the stump.

p.verse: 1This took place during the reign of Ahaz, son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah: Aram’s King Rezin and Israel’s King Pekah son of Remaliah went to fight against Jerusalem, but they were not able to conquer it.
2When it became known to the house of David that Aram had occupied Ephraim, the heart of Ahaz and the hearts of his people trembled like trees of a forest shaking in the wind.
3The Lord said to Isaiah, ‘Go out with your son Shear-jashub to meet Ahaz at the end of the conduit of the upper pool, by the road to the Launderer’s Field.
4Say to him: Calm down and be quiet. Don’t be afraid or cowardly because of these two smouldering sticks, the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram, and the son of Remaliah.
5For Aram, along with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah, has plotted harm against you. They say,
6“Let’s go up against Judah, terrorise it, and conquer it for ourselves. Then we can install Tabeel’s son as king in it.” ’
7This is what the Lord God says:

poetryblock.poem: It will not happen; it will not occur.

poem.verse: 8The chief city of Aram is Damascus,

poetryblock.poem: the chief of Damascus is Rezin
(within sixty-five years
Ephraim will be too shattered to be a people),

poem.verse: 9the chief city of Ephraim is Samaria,

poetryblock.poem: and the chief of Samaria is the son of Remaliah.
If you do not stand firm in your faith,
then you will not stand at all.

p.verse: 10Then the Lord spoke again to Ahaz:
11‘Ask for a sign from the Lord your God ​– ​it can be as deep as Sheol or as high as heaven.’
12But Ahaz replied, ‘I will not ask. I will not test the Lord.’
13Isaiah said, ‘Listen, house of David! Is it not enough for you to try the patience of men? Will you also try the patience of my God?
14Therefore, the Lord himself will give you a sign: See, the virgin will conceive, have a son, and name him Immanuel.
15By the time he learns to reject what is bad and choose what is good, he will be eating curds and honey.
16For before the boy knows to reject what is bad and choose what is good, the land of the two kings you dread will be abandoned.
17The Lord will bring on you, your people, and your father’s house such a time as has never been since Ephraim separated from Judah: He will bring the king of Assyria.’

poem.verse: 18On that day

poetryblock.poem: the Lord will whistle to flies
at the farthest streams of the Nile
and to bees in the land of Assyria.

poem.verse: 19All of them will come and settle

poetryblock.poem: in the steep ravines, in the clefts of the rocks,
in all the thorn bushes, and in all the water holes.

p.verse: 20On that day the Lord will use a razor hired from beyond the River Euphrates ​– ​the king of Assyria ​– ​to shave the hair on your heads, the hair on your legs, and even your beards.

poem.verse: 21On that day

poetryblock.poem: a man will raise a young cow and two sheep,

poem.verse: 22and from the abundant milk they give

poetryblock.poem: he will eat curds,
for every survivor in the land will eat curds and honey.

poem.verse: 23And on that day

poetryblock.poem: every place where there were a thousand vines,
worth a thousand pieces of silver,
will become thorns and briars.

poem.verse: 24A man will go there with bow and arrows

poetryblock.poem: because the whole land will be thorns and briars.

poem.verse: 25You will not go to all the hills

poetryblock.poem: that were once tilled with a hoe,
for fear of the thorns and briars.
Those hills will be places for oxen to graze
and for sheep to trample.

p.verse: 1Then the Lord said to me, ‘Take a large piece of parchment and write on it with an ordinary pen: Maher-shalal-hash-baz.
2I have appointed trustworthy witnesses ​– ​the priest Uriah and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah.’
3I was then intimate with the prophetess, and she conceived and gave birth to a son. The Lord said to me, ‘Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz,
4for before the boy knows how to call “Father”, or “Mother”, the wealth of Damascus and the spoils of Samaria will be carried off to the king of Assyria.’
5The Lord spoke to me again:

poem.verse: 6Because these people rejected

poetryblock.poem: the slowly flowing water of Shiloah
and rejoiced with Rezin
and the son of Remaliah,

poem.verse: 7the Lord will certainly bring against them

poetryblock.poem: the mighty rushing water of the River Euphrates –
the king of Assyria and all his glory.
It will overflow its channels
and spill over all its banks.

poem.verse: 8It will pour into Judah,

poetryblock.poem: flood over it, and sweep through,
reaching up to the neck;
and its flooded banks
will fill your entire land, Immanuel!

poem.verse: 9Band together, peoples, and be broken;

poetryblock.poem: pay attention, all you distant lands;
prepare for war, and be broken;
prepare for war, and be broken.

poem.verse: 10Devise a plan; it will fail.

poetryblock.poem: Make a prediction; it will not happen.
For God is with us.

chapter.head1: The Lord of Armies, the Only Refuge

p.verse: 11For this is what the Lord said to me with great power, to keep me from going the way of this people:

poem.verse: 12Do not call everything a conspiracy

poetryblock.poem: that these people say is a conspiracy.
Do not fear what they fear;
do not be terrified.

poem.verse: 13You are to regard only the Lord of Armies as holy.

poetryblock.poem: Only he should be feared;
only he should be held in awe.

poem.verse: 14He will be a sanctuary;

poetryblock.poem: but for the two houses of Israel,
he will be a stone to stumble over
and a rock to trip over,
and a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 15Many will stumble over these;

poetryblock.poem: they will fall and be broken;
they will be snared and captured.

poem.verse: 16Bind up the testimony.

poetryblock.poem: Seal up the instruction among my disciples.

poem.verse: 17I will wait for the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: who is hiding his face from the house of Jacob.
I will wait for him.

p.verse: 18Here I am with the children the Lord has given me to be signs and wonders in Israel from the Lord of Armies who dwells on Mount Zion.
19When they say to you, ‘Enquire of the mediums and the spiritists who chirp and mutter,’ shouldn’t a people enquire of their God? Should they enquire of the dead on behalf of the living?
20Go to God’s instruction and testimony! If they do not speak according to this word, there will be no dawn for them.
21They will wander through the land, dejected and hungry. When they are famished, they will become enraged, and, looking upwards, will curse their king and their God.
22They will look towards the earth and see only distress, darkness, and the gloom of affliction, and they will be driven into thick darkness.

chapter.head1: Birth of the Prince of Peace

p.verse: 1Nevertheless, the gloom of the distressed land will not be like that of the former times when he humbled the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali. But in the future he will bring honour to the way of the sea, to the land east of the Jordan, and to Galilee of the nations.

poem.verse: 2The people walking in darkness

poetryblock.poem: have seen a great light;
a light has dawned
on those living in the land of darkness.

poem.verse: 3You have enlarged the nation

poetryblock.poem: and increased its joy.
The people have rejoiced before you
as they rejoice at harvest time
and as they rejoice when dividing spoils.

poem.verse: 4For you have shattered their oppressive yoke

poetryblock.poem: and the rod on their shoulders,
the staff of their oppressor,
just as you did on the day of Midian.

poem.verse: 5For every trampling boot of battle

poetryblock.poem: and the bloodied garments of war
will be burned as fuel for the fire.

poem.verse: 6For a child will be born for us,

poetryblock.poem: a son will be given to us,
and the government will be on his shoulders.
He will be named
Wonderful Counsellor, Mighty God,
Eternal Father, Prince of Peace.

poem.verse: 7The dominion will be vast,

poetryblock.poem: and its prosperity will never end.
He will reign on the throne of David
and over his kingdom,
to establish and sustain it
with justice and righteousness from now on and for ever.
The zeal of the Lord of Armies will accomplish this.

poem.verse: 8The Lord sent a message against Jacob;

poetryblock.poem: it came against Israel.

poem.verse: 9All the people –

poetryblock.poem: Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria ​– ​will know it.
They will say with pride and arrogance,

poem.verse: 10‘The bricks have fallen,

poetryblock.poem: but we will rebuild with cut stones;
the sycamores have been cut down,
but we will replace them with cedars.’

poem.verse: 11The Lord has raised up Rezin’s adversaries against him

poetryblock.poem: and stirred up his enemies.

poem.verse: 12Aram from the east and Philistia from the west

poetryblock.poem: have consumed Israel with open mouths.
In all this, his anger has not turned away,
and his hand is still raised to strike.

poem.verse: 13The people did not turn to him who struck them;

poetryblock.poem: they did not seek the Lord of Armies.

poem.verse: 14So the Lord cut off Israel’s head and tail,

poetryblock.poem: palm branch and reed in a single day.

poem.verse: 15The head is the elder, the honoured one;

poetryblock.poem: the tail is the prophet, the one teaching lies.

poem.verse: 16The leaders of the people mislead them,

poetryblock.poem: and those they mislead are swallowed up.

poem.verse: 17Therefore the Lord does not rejoice

poetryblock.poem: over Israel’s young men
and has no compassion
on its fatherless and widows,
for everyone is a godless evildoer,
and every mouth speaks folly.
In all this, his anger has not turned away,
and his hand is still raised to strike.

poem.verse: 18For wickedness burns like a fire

poetryblock.poem: that consumes thorns and briars
and kindles the forest thickets
so that they go up in a column of smoke.

poem.verse: 19The land is scorched

poetryblock.poem: by the wrath of the Lord of Armies,
and the people are like fuel for the fire.
No one has compassion on his brother.

poem.verse: 20They carve meat on the right,

poetryblock.poem: but they are still hungry;
they have eaten on the left,
but they are still not satisfied.
Each one eats the flesh of his arm.

poem.verse: 21Manasseh eats Ephraim,

poetryblock.poem: and Ephraim, Manasseh;
together, both are against Judah.
In all this, his anger has not turned away,
and his hand is still raised to strike.

poem.verse: 1Woe to those enacting crooked statutes

poetryblock.poem: and writing oppressive laws

poem.verse: 2to keep the poor from getting a fair trial

poetryblock.poem: and to deprive the needy among my people of justice,
so that widows can be their spoil
and they can plunder the fatherless.

poem.verse: 3What will you do on the day of punishment

poetryblock.poem: when devastation comes from far away?
Who will you run to for help?
Where will you leave your wealth?

poem.verse: 4There will be nothing to do

poetryblock.poem: except crouch among the prisoners
or fall among the slain.
In all this, his anger has not turned away,
and his hand is still raised to strike.

poem.verse: 5Woe to Assyria, the rod of my anger –

poetryblock.poem: the staff in their hands is my wrath.

poem.verse: 6I will send him against a godless nation;

poetryblock.poem: I will command him to go
against a people destined for my rage,
to take spoils, to plunder,
and to trample them down like clay in the streets.

poem.verse: 7But this is not what he intends;

poetryblock.poem: this is not what he plans.
It is his intent to destroy
and to cut off many nations.

poem.verse: 8For he says,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Aren’t all my commanders kings?

poem.verse: 9Isn’t Calno like Carchemish?

poetryblock.poem: Isn’t Hamath like Arpad?
Isn’t Samaria like Damascus?

poem.verse: 10As my hand seized the kingdoms of worthless images,

poetryblock.poem: kingdoms whose idols exceeded those of Jerusalem and Samaria,

poem.verse: 11and as I did to Samaria and its worthless images

poetryblock.poem: will I not also do to Jerusalem and its idols? ’

p.verse: 12But when the Lord finishes all his work against Mount Zion and Jerusalem, he will say, ‘I will punish the king of Assyria for his arrogant acts and the proud look in his eyes.’
13For he said:

poetryblock.poem: I have done this by my own strength
and wisdom, for I am clever.
I abolished the borders of nations
and plundered their treasures;
like a mighty warrior, I subjugated the inhabitants.

poem.verse: 14My hand has reached out, as if into a nest,

poetryblock.poem: to seize the wealth of the nations.
Like one gathering abandoned eggs,
I gathered the whole earth.
No wing fluttered;
no beak opened or chirped.

poem.verse: 15Does an axe exalt itself

poetryblock.poem: above the one who chops with it?
Does a saw magnify itself
above the one who saws with it?
It would be like a rod waving the ones who lift it!
It would be like a staff lifting the one who isn’t wood!

poem.verse: 16Therefore the Lord God of Armies

poetryblock.poem: will inflict an emaciating disease
on the well-fed of Assyria,
and he will kindle a burning fire
under its glory.

poem.verse: 17Israel’s Light will become a fire,

poetryblock.poem: and its Holy One, a flame.
In one day it will burn and consume Assyria’s thorns and thistles.

poem.verse: 18He will completely destroy

poetryblock.poem: the glory of its forests and orchards
as a sickness consumes a person.

poem.verse: 19The remaining trees of its forest

poetryblock.poem: will be so few in number
that a child could count them.

p.verse: 20On that day the remnant of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will no longer depend on the one who struck them, but they will faithfully depend on the Lord, the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 21The remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: to the Mighty God.

poem.verse: 22Israel, even if your people were as numerous

poetryblock.poem: as the sand of the sea,
only a remnant of them will return.
Destruction has been decreed;
justice overflows.

poem.verse: 23For throughout the land

poetryblock.poem: the Lord God of Armies
is carrying out a destruction that was decreed.

p.verse: 24Therefore, the Lord God of Armies says this: ‘My people who dwell in Zion, do not fear Assyria, though they strike you with a rod and raise their staff over you as the Egyptians did.
25In only a little while my wrath will be spent and my anger will turn to their destruction.’
26And the Lord of Armies will brandish a whip against him as he did when he struck Midian at the rock of Oreb; and he will raise his staff over the sea as he did in Egypt.

poem.verse: 27On that day

poetryblock.poem: his burden will fall from your shoulders,
and his yoke from your neck.
The yoke will be broken because your neck will be too large.

poem.verse: 28Assyria has come to Aiath

poetryblock.poem: and has gone through Migron,
storing their equipment at Michmash.

poem.verse: 29They crossed over at the ford, saying,

poetryblock.poem: ‘We will spend the night at Geba.’
The people of Ramah are trembling;
those at Gibeah of Saul have fled.

poem.verse: 30Cry aloud, daughter of Gallim!

poetryblock.poem: Listen, Laishah!
Anathoth is miserable.

poem.verse: 31Madmenah has fled.

poetryblock.poem: The inhabitants of Gebim have sought refuge.

poem.verse: 32Today the Assyrians will stand at Nob,

poetryblock.poem: shaking their fists at the mountain of Daughter Zion,
the hill of Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 33Look, the Lord God of Armies

poetryblock.poem: will chop off the branches with terrifying power,
and the tall trees will be cut down,
the high trees felled.

poem.verse: 34He is clearing the thickets of the forest with an axe,

poetryblock.poem: and Lebanon with its majesty will fall.

poem.verse: 1Then a shoot will grow from the stump of Jesse,

poetryblock.poem: and a branch from his roots will bear fruit.

poem.verse: 2The Spirit of the Lord will rest on him –

poetryblock.poem: a Spirit of wisdom and understanding,
a Spirit of counsel and strength,
a Spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the Lord.

poem.verse: 3His delight will be in the fear of the Lord.

poetryblock.poem: He will not judge
by what he sees with his eyes,
he will not execute justice
by what he hears with his ears,

poem.verse: 4but he will judge the poor righteously

poetryblock.poem: and execute justice for the oppressed of the land.
He will strike the land
with a sceptre from his mouth,
and he will kill the wicked
with a command from his lips.

poem.verse: 5Righteousness will be a belt round his hips;

poetryblock.poem: faithfulness will be a belt round his waist.

poem.verse: 6The wolf will dwell with the lamb,

poetryblock.poem: and the leopard will lie down with the goat.
The calf, the young lion, and the fattened calf will be together,
and a child will lead them.

poem.verse: 7The cow and the bear will graze,

poetryblock.poem: their young ones will lie down together,
and the lion will eat straw like cattle.

poem.verse: 8An infant will play beside the cobra’s pit,

poetryblock.poem: and a toddler will put his hand into a snake’s den.

poem.verse: 9They will not harm or destroy each other

poetryblock.poem: on my entire holy mountain,
for the land will be as full
of the knowledge of the Lord
as the sea is filled with water.

poem.verse: 10On that day the root of Jesse

poetryblock.poem: will stand as a banner for the peoples.
The nations will look to him for guidance,
and his resting place will be glorious.

p.verse: 11On that day the Lord will extend his hand a second time to recover the remnant of his people who survive ​– ​from Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and the coasts and islands of the west.

poem.verse: 12He will lift up a banner for the nations

poetryblock.poem: and gather the dispersed of Israel;
he will collect the scattered of Judah
from the four corners of the earth.

poem.verse: 13Ephraim’s envy will cease;

poetryblock.poem: Judah’s harassing will end.
Ephraim will no longer be envious of Judah,
and Judah will not harass Ephraim.

poem.verse: 14But they will swoop down

poetryblock.poem: on the Philistine flank to the west.
Together they will plunder the people of the east.
They will extend their power over Edom and Moab,
and the Ammonites will be their subjects.

poem.verse: 15The Lord will divide the Gulf of Suez.

poetryblock.poem: He will wave his hand over the Euphrates
with his mighty wind
and will split it into seven streams,
letting people walk through on foot.

poem.verse: 16There will be a road for the remnant of his people

poetryblock.poem: who will survive from Assyria,
as there was for Israel
when they came up from the land of Egypt.

poem.verse: 1On that day you will say:

poetryblock.poem: ‘I will give thanks to you, Lord,
although you were angry with me.
Your anger has turned away,
and you have comforted me.

poem.verse: 2Indeed, God is my salvation;

poetryblock.poem: I will trust him and not be afraid,
for the Lord, the Lord himself,
is my strength and my song.
He has become my salvation.’

poem.verse: 3You will joyfully draw water

poetryblock.poem: from the springs of salvation,

poem.verse: 4and on that day you will say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Give thanks to the Lord; proclaim his name!
Make his works known among the peoples.
Declare that his name is exalted.

poem.verse: 5Sing to the Lord, for he has done glorious things.

poetryblock.poem: Let this be known throughout the earth.

poem.verse: 6Cry out and sing, citizen of Zion,

poetryblock.poem: for the Holy One of Israel is among you
in his greatness.’

p.verse: 1A pronouncement concerning Babylon that Isaiah son of Amoz saw:

poem.verse: 2Lift up a banner on a barren mountain.

poetryblock.poem: Call out to them.
Signal with your hand, and they will go
through the gates of the nobles.

poem.verse: 3I have commanded my consecrated ones;

poetryblock.poem: yes, I have called my warriors,
who celebrate my triumph,
to execute my wrath.

poem.verse: 4Listen, a commotion on the mountains,

poetryblock.poem: like that of a mighty people!
Listen, an uproar among the kingdoms,
like nations being gathered together!
The Lord of Armies is mobilising an army for war.

poem.verse: 5They are coming from a distant land,

poetryblock.poem: from the farthest horizon –
the Lord and the weapons of his wrath –
to destroy the whole country.

poem.verse: 6Wail! For the day of the Lord is near.

poetryblock.poem: It will come as destruction from the Almighty.

poem.verse: 7Therefore everyone’s hands will become weak,

poetryblock.poem: and every man will lose heart.

poem.verse: 8They will be horrified;

poetryblock.poem: pain and agony will seize them;
they will be in anguish like a woman in labour.
They will look at each other,
their faces flushed with fear.

poem.verse: 9Look, the day of the Lord is coming –

poetryblock.poem: cruel, with fury and burning anger –
to make the earth a desolation
and to destroy its sinners.

poem.verse: 10Indeed, the stars of the sky and its constellations

poetryblock.poem: will not give their light.
The sun will be dark when it rises,
and the moon will not shine.

poem.verse: 11I will punish the world for its evil,

poetryblock.poem: and wicked people for their iniquities.
I will put an end to the pride of the arrogant
and humiliate the insolence of tyrants.

poem.verse: 12I will make a human scarcer than fine gold,

poetryblock.poem: and mankind rarer than the gold of Ophir.

poem.verse: 13Therefore I will make the heavens tremble,

poetryblock.poem: and the earth will shake from its foundations
at the wrath of the Lord of Armies,
on the day of his burning anger.

poem.verse: 14Like wandering gazelles

poetryblock.poem: and like sheep without a shepherd,
each one will turn to his own people,
each one will flee to his own land.

poem.verse: 15Whoever is found will be stabbed,

poetryblock.poem: and whoever is caught will die by the sword.

poem.verse: 16Their children will be dashed to pieces before their eyes;

poetryblock.poem: their houses will be looted,
and their wives raped.

poem.verse: 17Look! I am stirring up the Medes against them,

poetryblock.poem: who cannot be bought off with silver
and who have no desire for gold.

poem.verse: 18Their bows will cut young men to pieces.

poetryblock.poem: They will have no compassion on offspring;
they will not look with pity on children.

poem.verse: 19And Babylon, the jewel of the kingdoms,

poetryblock.poem: the glory of the pride of the Chaldeans,
will be like Sodom and Gomorrah
when God overthrew them.

poem.verse: 20It will never be inhabited

poetryblock.poem: or lived in from generation to generation;
a nomad will not pitch his tent there,
and shepherds will not let their flocks rest there.

poem.verse: 21But desert creatures will lie down there,

poetryblock.poem: and owls will fill the houses.
Ostriches will dwell there,
and wild goats will leap about.

poem.verse: 22Hyenas will howl in the fortresses,

poetryblock.poem: and jackals in the luxurious palaces.
Babylon’s time is almost up;
her days are almost over.

p.verse: 1For the Lord will have compassion on Jacob and will choose Israel again. He will settle them on their own land. The resident foreigner will join them and be united with the house of Jacob.

2The nations will escort Israel and bring it to its homeland. Then the house of Israel will possess them as male and female slaves in the Lord’s land. They will make captives of their captors and will rule over their oppressors.

chapter.head1: Downfall of the King of Babylon

p.verse: 3When the Lord gives you rest from your pain, torment, and the hard labour you were forced to do,
4you will sing this song of contempt about the king of Babylon and say:

poetryblock.poem: How the oppressor has quietened down,
and how the raging has become quiet!

poem.verse: 5The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: the sceptre of the rulers.

poem.verse: 6It struck the peoples in anger

poetryblock.poem: with unceasing blows.
It subdued the nations in rage
with relentless persecution.

poem.verse: 7The whole earth is calm and at rest;

poetryblock.poem: people shout with a ringing cry.

poem.verse: 8Even the cypresses and the cedars of Lebanon

poetryblock.poem: rejoice over you:
‘Since you have been laid low,
no woodcutter has come against us.’

poem.verse: 9Sheol below is eager to greet your coming,

poetryblock.poem: stirring up the spirits of the departed for you –
all the rulers of the earth –
making all the kings of the nations
rise from their thrones.

poem.verse: 10They all respond to you, saying,

poetryblock.poem: ‘You too have become as weak as we are;
you have become like us!

poem.verse: 11Your splendour has been brought down to Sheol,

poetryblock.poem: along with the music of your harps.
Maggots are spread out under you,
and worms cover you.’

poem.verse: 12Shining morning star,

poetryblock.poem: how you have fallen from the heavens!
You destroyer of nations,
you have been cut down to the ground.

poem.verse: 13You said to yourself,

poetryblock.poem: ‘I will ascend to the heavens;
I will set up my throne
above the stars of God.
I will sit on the mount of the gods’ assembly,
in the remotest parts of the North.

poem.verse: 14I will ascend above the highest clouds;

poetryblock.poem: I will make myself like the Most High.’

poem.verse: 15But you will be brought down to Sheol

poetryblock.poem: into the deepest regions of the Pit.

poem.verse: 16Those who see you will stare at you;

poetryblock.poem: they will look closely at you:
‘Is this the man who caused the earth to tremble,
who shook the kingdoms,

poem.verse: 17who turned the world into a wilderness,

poetryblock.poem: who destroyed its cities
and would not release the prisoners to return home? ’

poem.verse: 18All the kings of the nations

poetryblock.poem: lie in splendour, each in his own tomb.

poem.verse: 19But you are thrown out without a grave,

poetryblock.poem: like a worthless branch,
covered by those slain with the sword
and dumped into a rocky pit like a trampled corpse.

poem.verse: 20You will not join them in burial,

poetryblock.poem: because you destroyed your land
and slaughtered your own people.
The offspring of evildoers
will never be mentioned again.

poem.verse: 21Prepare a place of slaughter for his sons,

poetryblock.poem: because of the iniquity of their ancestors.
They will never rise up to possess a land
or fill the surface of the earth with cities.

p.verse: 22‘I will rise up against them’ ​– ​this is the declaration of the Lord of Armies ​– ​‘and I will cut off from Babylon her reputation, remnant, offspring, and posterity’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration.
23‘I will make her a swampland and a region for herons, and I will sweep her away with the broom of destruction.’

chapter.p: This is the declaration of the Lord of Armies.

p.verse: 24The Lord of Armies has sworn:

poetryblock.poem: As I have purposed, so it will be;
as I have planned it, so it will happen.

poem.verse: 25I will break Assyria in my land;

poetryblock.poem: I will tread him down on my mountain.
Then his yoke will be taken from them,
and his burden will be removed from their shoulders.

poem.verse: 26This is the plan prepared

poetryblock.poem: for the whole earth,
and this is the hand stretched out
against all the nations.

poem.verse: 27The Lord of Armies himself has planned it;

poetryblock.poem: therefore, who can stand in its way?
It is his hand that is outstretched,
so who can turn it back?

p.verse: 28In the year that King Ahaz died, this pronouncement came:

poem.verse: 29Don’t rejoice, all of you in Philistia,

poetryblock.poem: because the rod of the one who struck you is broken.
For a viper will come from the root of a snake,
and from its egg comes a flying serpent.

poem.verse: 30Then the firstborn of the poor will be well fed,

poetryblock.poem: and the impoverished will lie down in safety,
but I will kill your root with hunger,
and your remnant will be slain.

poem.verse: 31Wail, you gates! Cry out, city!

poetryblock.poem: Tremble with fear, all Philistia!
For a cloud of dust is coming from the north,
and there is no one missing from the invader’s ranks.

poem.verse: 32What answer will be given to the messengers from that nation?

poetryblock.poem: The Lord has founded Zion,
and his oppressed people find refuge in her.

p.verse: 1A pronouncement concerning Moab:

poetryblock.poem: Ar in Moab is devastated,
destroyed in a night.
Kir in Moab is devastated,
destroyed in a night.

poem.verse: 2Dibon went up to its temple

poetryblock.poem: to weep at its high places.
Moab wails on Nebo and at Medeba.
Every head is shaved;
every beard is chopped short.

poem.verse: 3In its streets they wear sackcloth;

poetryblock.poem: on its rooftops and in its public squares everyone wails,
falling down and weeping.

poem.verse: 4Heshbon and Elealeh cry out;

poetryblock.poem: their voices are heard as far away as Jahaz.
Therefore the soldiers of Moab cry out,
and they tremble.

poem.verse: 5My heart cries out over Moab,

poetryblock.poem: whose fugitives flee as far as Zoar,
to Eglath-shelishiyah;
they go up the Ascent of Luhith weeping;
they raise a cry of destruction
on the road to Horonaim.

poem.verse: 6The Waters of Nimrim are desolate;

poetryblock.poem: the grass is withered, the foliage is gone,
and the vegetation has vanished.

poem.verse: 7So they carry their wealth and belongings

poetryblock.poem: over the Wadi of the Willows.

poem.verse: 8For their cry echoes

poetryblock.poem: throughout the territory of Moab.
Their wailing reaches Eglaim;
their wailing reaches Beer-elim.

poem.verse: 9The Waters of Dibon are full of blood,

poetryblock.poem: but I will bring on Dibon even more than this –
a lion for those who escape from Moab,
and for the survivors in the land.

poem.verse: 1Send lambs to the ruler of the land,

poetryblock.poem: from Sela in the desert
to the mountain of Daughter Zion.

poem.verse: 2Like a bird fleeing,

poetryblock.poem: forced from the nest,
the daughters of Moab
will be at the fords of the Arnon.

poem.verse: 3Give us counsel and make a decision.

poetryblock.poem: Shelter us at noonday
with shade that is as dark as night.
Hide the refugees;
do not betray the one who flees.

poem.verse: 4Let my refugees stay with you;

poetryblock.poem: be a refuge for Moab from the aggressor.
When the oppressor has gone,
destruction has ended,
and marauders have vanished from the land,

poem.verse: 5a throne will be established in love,

poetryblock.poem: and one will sit on it faithfully
in the tent of David,
judging and pursuing what is right,
quick to execute justice.

poem.verse: 6We have heard of Moab’s pride –

poetryblock.poem: how very proud he is –
his haughtiness, his pride, his arrogance,
and his empty boasting.

poem.verse: 7Therefore let Moab wail;

poetryblock.poem: let every one of them wail for Moab.
You who are completely devastated, mourn
for the raisin cakes of Kir-hareseth.

poem.verse: 8For Heshbon’s terraced vineyards

poetryblock.poem: and the grapevines of Sibmah have withered.
The rulers of the nations
have trampled its choice vines
that reached as far as Jazer
and spread to the desert.
Their shoots spread out
and reached the sea.

poem.verse: 9So I join with Jazer

poetryblock.poem: to weep for the vines of Sibmah;
I drench Heshbon and Elealeh with my tears.
Triumphant shouts have fallen silent
over your summer fruit and your harvest.

poem.verse: 10Joy and rejoicing have been removed from the orchard;

poetryblock.poem: no one is singing or shouting for joy in the vineyards.
No one tramples grapes in the winepresses.
I have put an end to the shouting.

poem.verse: 11Therefore I moan like the sound of a lyre for Moab,

poetryblock.poem: as does my innermost being for Kir-heres.

poem.verse: 12When Moab appears

poetryblock.poem: and tires himself out on the high place
and comes to his sanctuary to pray,
it will do him no good.

p.verse: 13This is the message that the Lord previously announced about Moab.

14And now the Lord says, ‘In three years, as a hired worker counts years, Moab’s splendour will become an object of contempt, in spite of a very large population. And those who are left will be few and weak.’
1A pronouncement concerning Damascus:

poetryblock.poem: Look, Damascus is no longer a city.
It has become a ruined heap.

poem.verse: 2The cities of Aroer are abandoned;

poetryblock.poem: they will be places for flocks.
They will lie down without fear.

poem.verse: 3The fortress disappears from Ephraim,

poetryblock.poem: and a kingdom from Damascus.
The remnant of Aram will be
like the splendour of the Israelites.

chapter.p: This is the declaration of the Lord of Armies.

poem.verse: 4On that day

poetryblock.poem: the splendour of Jacob will fade,
and his healthy body will become emaciated.

poem.verse: 5It will be as if a reaper had gathered standing corn –

poetryblock.poem: his arm harvesting the ears of corn –
and as if one had gleaned ears of corn
in Rephaim Valley.

poem.verse: 6Only gleanings will be left in Israel,

poetryblock.poem: as if an olive tree had been beaten –
two or three olives at the very top of the tree,
four or five on its fruitful branches.
This is the declaration of the Lord,
the God of Israel.

p.verse: 7On that day people will look to their Maker and will turn their eyes to the Holy One of Israel.
8They will not look to the altars they made with their hands or to the Asherahs and shrines they made with their fingers.

poem.verse: 9On that day their strong cities will be

poetryblock.poem: like the abandoned woods and mountaintops
that were abandoned because of the Israelites;
there will be desolation.

poem.verse: 10For you have forgotten the God of your salvation,

poetryblock.poem: and you have failed to remember
the rock of your strength;
therefore you will plant beautiful plants
and set out cuttings from exotic vines.

poem.verse: 11On the day that you plant,

poetryblock.poem: you will help them to grow,
and in the morning
you will help your seed to sprout,
but the harvest will vanish
on the day of disease and incurable pain.

poem.verse: 12Ah! The roar of many peoples –

poetryblock.poem: they roar like the roaring of the seas.
The raging of the nations –
they rage like the rumble of rushing water.

poem.verse: 13The nations rage like the rumble of a huge torrent.

poetryblock.poem: He rebukes them, and they flee far away,
driven before the wind like chaff on the hills
and like tumbleweeds before a gale.

poem.verse: 14In the evening ​– ​sudden terror!

poetryblock.poem: Before morning ​– ​it is gone!
This is the fate of those who plunder us
and the lot of those who ravage us.

poem.verse: 1Woe to the land of buzzing insect wings

poetryblock.poem: beyond the rivers of Cush,

poem.verse: 2which sends envoys by sea,

poetryblock.poem: in reed vessels over the water.
Go, swift messengers,
to a nation tall and smooth-skinned,
to a people feared far and near,
a powerful nation with a strange language,
whose land is divided by rivers.

poem.verse: 3All you inhabitants of the world

poetryblock.poem: and you who live on the earth,
when a banner is raised on the mountains, look!
When a ram’s horn sounds, listen!

p.verse: 4For the Lord said to me:

poetryblock.poem: I will quietly look out from my place,
like shimmering heat in sunshine,
like a rain cloud in harvest heat.

poem.verse: 5For before the harvest, when the blossoming is over

poetryblock.poem: and the blossom becomes a ripening grape,
he will cut off the shoots with a pruning knife,
and tear away and remove the branches.

poem.verse: 6They will all be left for the birds of prey on the hills

poetryblock.poem: and for the wild animals of the land.
The birds of prey will spend the summer feeding on them,
and all the wild animals the winter.

p.verse: 7At that time a gift will be brought to the Lord of Armies from a people tall and smooth-skinned, a people feared far and near, a powerful nation with a strange language, whose land is divided by rivers ​– ​to Mount Zion, the place of the name of the Lord of Armies.
1A pronouncement concerning Egypt:

poetryblock.poem: Look, the Lord rides on a swift cloud
and is coming to Egypt.
Egypt’s worthless idols will tremble before him,
and Egypt will lose heart.

poem.verse: 2I will provoke Egyptians against Egyptians;

poetryblock.poem: each will fight against his brother
and each against his friend,
city against city, kingdom against kingdom.

poem.verse: 3Egypt’s spirit will be disturbed within it,

poetryblock.poem: and I will frustrate its plans.
Then they will enquire of worthless idols, ghosts,
mediums, and spiritists.

poem.verse: 4I will hand over Egypt to harsh masters,

poetryblock.poem: and a strong king will rule it.
This is the declaration of the Lord God of Armies.

poem.verse: 5The water of the sea will dry up,

poetryblock.poem: and the river will be parched and dry.

poem.verse: 6The channels will stink;

poetryblock.poem: they will dwindle, and Egypt’s canals will be parched.
Reed and rush will wilt.

poem.verse: 7The reeds by the Nile, by the mouth of the river,

poetryblock.poem: and all the cultivated areas of the Nile
will wither, blow away, and vanish.

poem.verse: 8Then the fishermen will mourn.

poetryblock.poem: All those who cast hooks into the Nile will lament,
and those who spread nets on the water will give up.

poem.verse: 9Those who work with flax will be dismayed;

poetryblock.poem: those combing it and weaving linen will turn pale.

poem.verse: 10Egypt’s weavers will be dejected;

poetryblock.poem: all her wage earners will be demoralised.

poem.verse: 11The princes of Zoan are complete fools;

poetryblock.poem: Pharaoh’s wisest advisers give stupid advice!
How can you say to Pharaoh,
‘I am one of the wise,
a student of eastern kings’?

poem.verse: 12Where then are your wise men?

poetryblock.poem: Let them tell you and reveal
what the Lord of Armies has planned against Egypt.

poem.verse: 13The princes of Zoan have been fools;

poetryblock.poem: the princes of Memphis are deceived.
Her tribal chieftains have led Egypt astray.

poem.verse: 14The Lord has mixed within her a spirit of confusion.

poetryblock.poem: The leaders have made Egypt stagger in all she does,
as a drunkard staggers in his vomit.

poem.verse: 15No head or tail, palm or reed,

poetryblock.poem: will be able to do anything for Egypt.

p.verse: 16On that day Egypt will be like women and will tremble with fear because of the threatening hand of the Lord of Armies when he raises it against them.
17The land of Judah will terrify Egypt; whenever Judah is mentioned, Egypt will tremble because of what the Lord of Armies has planned against it.
18On that day five cities in the land of Egypt will speak the language of Canaan and swear loyalty to the Lord of Armies. One of the cities will be called the City of the Sun.
19On that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the centre of the land of Egypt and a pillar to the Lord near her border.
20It will be a sign and witness to the Lord of Armies in the land of Egypt. When they cry out to the Lord because of their oppressors, he will send them a saviour and leader, and he will rescue them.
21The Lord will make himself known to Egypt, and Egypt will know the Lord on that day. They will offer sacrifices and offerings; they will make vows to the Lord and fulfil them.
22The Lord will strike Egypt, striking and healing. Then they will turn to the Lord, and he will be receptive to their prayers and heal them.
23On that day there will be a road from Egypt to Assyria. Assyria will go to Egypt, Egypt to Assyria, and Egypt will worship with Assyria.
24On that day Israel will form a triple alliance with Egypt and Assyria ​– ​a blessing within the land.
25The Lord of Armies will bless them, saying, ‘Egypt my people, Assyria my handiwork, and Israel my inheritance are blessed.’

chapter.head1: No Help from Cush or Egypt

p.verse: 1In the year that the chief commander, sent by King Sargon of Assyria, came to Ashdod and attacked and captured it ​– ​

2during that time the Lord had spoken through Isaiah son of Amoz, saying, ‘Go, take off your sackcloth from your waist and remove the sandals from your feet,’ and he did that, going stripped and barefoot ​– ​
3the Lord said, ‘As my servant Isaiah has gone stripped and barefoot three years as a sign and omen against Egypt and Cush,
4so the king of Assyria will lead the captives of Egypt and the exiles of Cush, young and old alike, stripped and barefoot, with bared buttocks ​– ​to Egypt’s shame.
5Those who made Cush their hope and Egypt their boast will be dismayed and ashamed.

6And the inhabitants of this coastland will say on that day, “Look, this is what has happened to those we relied on and fled to for help to rescue us from the king of Assyria! Now, how will we escape? ” ’
1A pronouncement concerning the desert by the sea:

poetryblock.poem: Like storms that pass over the Negev,
it comes from the desert, from the land of terror.

poem.verse: 2A troubling vision is declared to me:

poetryblock.poem: ‘The treacherous one acts treacherously,
and the destroyer destroys.
Advance, Elam! Lay siege, you Medes!
I will put an end to all the groaning.’

poem.verse: 3Therefore I am filled with anguish.

poetryblock.poem: Pain grips me, like the pain of a woman in labour.
I am too perplexed to hear,
too dismayed to see.

poem.verse: 4My heart staggers;

poetryblock.poem: horror terrifies me.
He has turned my last glimmer of hope
into sheer terror.

poem.verse: 5Prepare a table, and spread out a carpet!

poetryblock.poem: Eat and drink!
Rise up, you princes, and oil the shields!

poem.verse: 6For the Lord has said to me,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Go, post a lookout;
let him report what he sees.

poem.verse: 7When he sees riders –

poetryblock.poem: pairs of horsemen,
riders on donkeys,
riders on camels –
he must pay close attention.’

poem.verse: 8Then the lookout reported,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Lord, I stand on the watchtower all day,
and I stay at my post all night.

poem.verse: 9Look, riders come –

poetryblock.poem: horsemen in pairs.’
And he answered, saying,
‘Babylon has fallen, has fallen.
All the images of her gods
have been shattered on the ground.’

poem.verse: 10My people who have been crushed

poetryblock.poem: on the threshing-floor,
I have declared to you
what I have heard from the Lord of Armies,
the God of Israel.

p.verse: 11A pronouncement concerning Dumah:

poetryblock.poem: One calls to me from Seir,
‘Watchman, what is left of the night?
Watchman, what is left of the night? ’

poem.verse: 12The watchman said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Morning has come, and also night.
If you want to ask, ask!
Come back again.’

p.verse: 13A pronouncement concerning Arabia:

poetryblock.poem: In the desert brush
you will camp for the night,
you caravans of Dedanites.

poem.verse: 14Bring water for the thirsty.

poetryblock.poem: The inhabitants of the land of Tema
meet the refugees with food.

poem.verse: 15For they have fled from swords,

poetryblock.poem: from the drawn sword,
from the bow that is strung,
and from the stress of battle.

p.verse: 16For the Lord said this to me: ‘Within one year, as a hired worker counts years, all the glory of Kedar will be gone.
17The remaining Kedarite archers will be few in number.’ For the Lord, the God of Israel, has spoken.
1A pronouncement concerning the Valley of Vision:

poetryblock.poem: What’s the matter with you?
Why have all of you gone up to the rooftops?

poem.verse: 2The noisy city, the jubilant town,

poetryblock.poem: is filled with celebration.
Your dead did not die by the sword;
they were not killed in battle.

poem.verse: 3All your rulers have fled together,

poetryblock.poem: captured without a bow.
All your fugitives were captured together;
they had fled far away.

poem.verse: 4Therefore I said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Look away from me! Let me weep bitterly!
Do not try to comfort me
about the destruction of my dear people.’

poem.verse: 5For the Lord God of Armies

poetryblock.poem: had a day of tumult, trampling, and confusion
in the Valley of Vision –
people shouting and crying to the mountains;

poem.verse: 6Elam took up a quiver

poetryblock.poem: with chariots and horsemen,
and Kir uncovered the shield.

poem.verse: 7Your best valleys were full of chariots,

poetryblock.poem: and horsemen were positioned at the city gates.

poem.verse: 8He removed the defences of Judah.

chapter.p: On that day you looked to the weapons in the House of the Forest. 9You saw that there were many breaches in the walls of the city of David. You collected water from the lower pool.10You counted the houses of Jerusalem so that you could tear them down to fortify the wall.11You made a reservoir between the walls for the water of the ancient pool, but you did not look to the one who made it, or consider the one who created it long ago.

poem.verse: 12On that day the Lord God of Armies

poetryblock.poem: called for weeping, for wailing, for shaven heads,
and for the wearing of sackcloth.

poem.verse: 13But look: joy and gladness,

poetryblock.poem: butchering of cattle, slaughtering of sheep and goats,
eating of meat, and drinking of wine –
‘Let’s eat and drink, for tomorrow we die! ’

poem.verse: 14The Lord of Armies has directly revealed to me:

poetryblock.poem: ‘This iniquity will not be wiped out for you people as long as you live.’
The Lord God of Armies has spoken.

p.verse: 15The Lord God of Armies said, ‘Go to Shebna, that steward who is in charge of the palace, and say to him:
16What are you doing here? Who authorised you to carve out a tomb for yourself here, carving your tomb on the height and cutting a resting place for yourself out of rock?
17Look, you strong man! The Lord is about to shake you violently. He will take hold of you,
18wind you up into a ball, and sling you into a wide land. There you will die, and there your glorious chariots will be ​– ​a disgrace to the house of your lord.
19I will remove you from your office; you will be ousted from your position.
20‘On that day I will call for my servant, Eliakim son of Hilkiah.
21I will clothe him with your robe and tie your sash round him. I will hand your authority over to him, and he will be like a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.
22I will place the key of the house of David on his shoulder; what he opens, no one can close; what he closes, no one can open.
23I will drive him, like a peg, into a firm place. He will be a throne of honour for his father’s family.
24They will hang on him all the glory of his father’s family: the descendants and the offshoots ​– ​all the small vessels, from bowls to every kind of jar.

25On that day’ ​– ​the declaration of the Lord of Armies ​– ​‘the peg that was driven into a firm place will give way, be cut off, and fall, and the load on it will be destroyed.’ Indeed, the Lord has spoken.
1A pronouncement concerning Tyre:

poetryblock.poem: Wail, ships of Tarshish,
for your haven has been destroyed.
Word has reached them from the land of Cyprus.

poem.verse: 2Mourn, inhabitants of the coastland,

poetryblock.poem: you merchants of Sidon;
your agents have crossed the sea

poem.verse: 3over deep water.

poetryblock.poem: Tyre’s revenue was the grain from Shihor –
the harvest of the Nile.
She was the merchant among the nations.

poem.verse: 4Be ashamed, Sidon, the stronghold of the sea,

poetryblock.poem: for the sea has spoken:
‘I have not been in labour or given birth.
I have not raised young men
or brought up young women.’

poem.verse: 5When the news reaches Egypt,

poetryblock.poem: they will be in anguish over the news about Tyre.

poem.verse: 6Cross over to Tarshish;

poetryblock.poem: wail, inhabitants of the coastland!

poem.verse: 7Is this your jubilant city,

poetryblock.poem: whose origin was in ancient times,
whose feet have taken her
to reside far away?

poem.verse: 8Who planned this against Tyre,

poetryblock.poem: the bestower of crowns,
whose traders are princes,
whose merchants are the honoured ones of the earth?

poem.verse: 9The Lord of Armies planned it,

poetryblock.poem: to desecrate all its glorious beauty,
to disgrace all the honoured ones of the earth.

poem.verse: 10Overflow your land like the Nile, daughter of Tarshish;

poetryblock.poem: there is no longer anything to restrain you.

poem.verse: 11He stretched out his hand over the sea;

poetryblock.poem: he made kingdoms tremble.
The Lord has commanded
that the Canaanite fortresses be destroyed.

poem.verse: 12He said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘You will not celebrate any more,
ravished young woman, daughter of Sidon.
Get up and cross over to Cyprus –
even there you will have no rest! ’

poem.verse: 13Look at the land of the Chaldeans –

poetryblock.poem: a people who no longer exist.
Assyria destined it for desert creatures.
They set up their siege towers
and stripped its palaces.
They made it a ruin.

poem.verse: 14Wail, ships of Tarshish,

poetryblock.poem: because your fortress is destroyed!

p.verse: 15On that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years ​– ​the lifespan of one king. At the end of seventy years, what the song says about the prostitute will happen to Tyre:

poem.verse: 16Pick up your lyre,

poetryblock.poem: stroll through the city,
you forgotten prostitute.
Play skilfully,
sing many a song
so that you will be remembered.

p.verse: 17And at the end of the seventy years, the Lord will restore Tyre and she will go back into business, prostituting herself with all the kingdoms of the world throughout the earth.

18But her profits and wages will be dedicated to the Lord. They will not be stored or saved, for her profit will go to those who live in the Lord’s presence, to provide them with ample food and sacred clothing.

poem.verse: 1Look, the Lord is stripping the earth bare

poetryblock.poem: and making it desolate.
He will twist its surface and scatter its inhabitants:

poem.verse: 2people and priest alike,

poetryblock.poem: servant and master,
female servant and mistress,
buyer and seller,
lender and borrower,
creditor and debtor.

poem.verse: 3The earth will be stripped completely bare

poetryblock.poem: and will be totally plundered,
for the Lord has spoken this message.

poem.verse: 4The earth mourns and withers;

poetryblock.poem: the world wastes away and withers;
the exalted people of the earth waste away.

poem.verse: 5The earth is polluted by its inhabitants,

poetryblock.poem: for they have transgressed teachings,
overstepped decrees,
and broken the permanent covenant.

poem.verse: 6Therefore a curse has consumed the earth,

poetryblock.poem: and its inhabitants have become guilty;
the earth’s inhabitants have been burned,
and only a few survive.

poem.verse: 7The new wine mourns;

poetryblock.poem: the vine withers.
All the carousers now groan.

poem.verse: 8The joyful tambourines have ceased.

poetryblock.poem: The noise of the jubilant has stopped.
The joyful lyre has ceased.

poem.verse: 9They no longer sing and drink wine;

poetryblock.poem: beer is bitter to those who drink it.

poem.verse: 10The city of chaos is shattered;

poetryblock.poem: every house is closed to entry.

poem.verse: 11In the streets they cry for wine.

poetryblock.poem: All joy grows dark;
earth’s rejoicing goes into exile.

poem.verse: 12Only desolation remains in the city;

poetryblock.poem: its gate has collapsed in ruins.

poem.verse: 13For this is how it will be on earth

poetryblock.poem: among the nations:
like a harvested olive tree,
like a gleaning after a grape harvest.

poem.verse: 14They raise their voices, they sing out;

poetryblock.poem: they proclaim in the west
the majesty of the Lord.

poem.verse: 15Therefore, in the east honour the Lord!

poetryblock.poem: In the coasts and islands of the west
honour the name of the Lord,
the God of Israel.

poem.verse: 16From the ends of the earth we hear songs:

poetryblock.poem: The Splendour of the Righteous One.
But I said, ‘I waste away! I waste away!
Woe is me.’
The treacherous act treacherously;
the treacherous deal very treacherously.

poem.verse: 17Panic, pit, and trap await you

poetryblock.poem: who dwell on the earth.

poem.verse: 18Whoever flees at the sound of panic

poetryblock.poem: will fall into a pit,
and whoever escapes from the pit
will be caught in a trap.
For the floodgates on high are opened,
and the foundations of the earth are shaken.

poem.verse: 19The earth is completely devastated;

poetryblock.poem: the earth is split open;
the earth is violently shaken.

poem.verse: 20The earth staggers like a drunkard

poetryblock.poem: and sways like a hut.
Earth’s rebellion weighs it down,
and it falls, never to rise again.

poem.verse: 21On that day the Lord will punish

poetryblock.poem: the army of the heights in the heights
and the kings of the ground on the ground.

poem.verse: 22They will be gathered together

poetryblock.poem: like prisoners in a pit.
They will be confined to a dungeon;
after many days they will be punished.

poem.verse: 23The moon will be put to shame

poetryblock.poem: and the sun disgraced,
because the Lord of Armies will reign as king
on Mount Zion in Jerusalem,
and he will display his glory
in the presence of his elders.

chapter.head1: Salvation and Judgement on That Day

poem.verse: 1Lord, you are my God;

poetryblock.poem: I will exalt you. I will praise your name,
for you have accomplished wonders,
plans formed long ago, with perfect faithfulness.

poem.verse: 2For you have turned the city into a pile of rocks,

poetryblock.poem: a fortified city into ruins;
the fortress of barbarians is no longer a city;
it will never be rebuilt.

poem.verse: 3Therefore, a strong people will honour you.

poetryblock.poem: The cities of violent nations will fear you.

poem.verse: 4For you have been a stronghold for the poor person,

poetryblock.poem: a stronghold for the needy in his distress,
a refuge from storms and a shade from heat.
When the breath of the violent
is like a storm against a wall,

poem.verse: 5like heat in a dry land,

poetryblock.poem: you will subdue the uproar of barbarians.
As the shade of a cloud cools the heat of the day,
so he will silence the song of the violent.

poem.verse: 6On this mountain,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord of Armies will prepare for all the peoples a feast of choice meat,
a feast with aged wine, prime cuts of choice meat, fine vintage wine.

poem.verse: 7On this mountain

poetryblock.poem: he will swallow up the burial shroud,
the shroud over all the peoples,
the sheet covering all the nations.

poem.verse: 8When he has swallowed up death once and for all,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord God will wipe away the tears
from every face
and remove his people’s disgrace
from the whole earth,
for the Lord has spoken.

poem.verse: 9On that day it will be said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Look, this is our God;
we have waited for him, and he has saved us.
This is the Lord; we have waited for him.
Let’s rejoice and be glad in his salvation.’

poem.verse: 10For the Lord’s power will rest on this mountain.

poetryblock.poem: But Moab will be trampled in his place
as straw is trampled in a dung pile.

poem.verse: 11He will spread out his arms in the middle of it,

poetryblock.poem: as a swimmer spreads out his arms to swim.
His pride will be brought low,
along with the trickery of his hands.

poem.verse: 12The high-walled fortress will be brought down,

poetryblock.poem: thrown to the ground, to the dust.

p.verse: 1On that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah:

poetryblock.poem: We have a strong city.
Salvation is established as walls and ramparts.

poem.verse: 2Open the gates

poetryblock.poem: so a righteous nation can come in –
one that remains faithful.

poem.verse: 3You will keep the mind that is dependent on you

poetryblock.poem: in perfect peace,
for it is trusting in you.

poem.verse: 4Trust in the Lord for ever,

poetryblock.poem: because in the Lord, the Lord himself, is an everlasting rock!

poem.verse: 5For he has humbled those who live in lofty places –

poetryblock.poem: an inaccessible city.
He brings it down; he brings it down to the ground;
he throws it to the dust.

poem.verse: 6Feet trample it,

poetryblock.poem: the feet of the humble,
the steps of the poor.

poem.verse: 7The path of the righteous is level;

poetryblock.poem: you clear a straight path for the righteous.

poem.verse: 8Yes, Lord, we wait for you

poetryblock.poem: in the path of your judgements.
Our desire is for your name and renown.

poem.verse: 9I long for you in the night;

poetryblock.poem: yes, my spirit within me diligently seeks you,
for when your judgements are in the land,
the inhabitants of the world will learn righteousness.

poem.verse: 10But if the wicked man is shown favour,

poetryblock.poem: he does not learn righteousness.
In a righteous land he acts unjustly
and does not see the majesty of the Lord.

poem.verse: 11Lord, your hand is lifted up to take action,

poetryblock.poem: but they do not see it.
Let them see your zeal for your people
and be put to shame.
Let fire consume your adversaries.

poem.verse: 12Lord, you will establish peace for us,

poetryblock.poem: for you have also done all our work for us.

poem.verse: 13Lord our God, lords other than you have owned us,

poetryblock.poem: but we remember your name alone.

poem.verse: 14The dead do not live;

poetryblock.poem: departed spirits do not rise up.
Indeed, you have punished and destroyed them;
you have wiped out all memory of them.

poem.verse: 15You have added to the nation, Lord.

poetryblock.poem: You have added to the nation; you are honoured.
You have expanded all the borders of the land.

poem.verse: 16Lord, they went to you in their distress;

poetryblock.poem: they poured out whispered prayers
because your discipline fell on them.

poem.verse: 17As a pregnant woman about to give birth

poetryblock.poem: writhes and cries out in her pains,
so we were before you, Lord.

poem.verse: 18We became pregnant, we writhed in pain;

poetryblock.poem: we gave birth to wind.
We have won no victories on earth,
and the earth’s inhabitants have not fallen.

poem.verse: 19Your dead will live; their bodies will rise.

poetryblock.poem: Awake and sing, you who dwell in the dust!
For you will be covered with the morning dew,
and the earth will bring out the departed spirits.

poem.verse: 20Go, my people, enter your rooms

poetryblock.poem: and close your doors behind you.
Hide for a little while until the wrath has passed.

poem.verse: 21For look, the Lord is coming from his place

poetryblock.poem: to punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity.
The earth will reveal the blood shed on it
and will no longer conceal her slain.

p.verse: 1On that day the Lord with his relentless, large, strong sword will bring judgement on Leviathan, the fleeing serpent ​– ​Leviathan, the twisting serpent. He will slay the monster that is in the sea.

poem.verse: 2On that day

poetryblock.poem: sing about a desirable vineyard:

poem.verse: 3I am the Lord, who watches over it

poetryblock.poem: to water it regularly.
So that no one disturbs it,
I watch over it night and day.

poem.verse: 4I am not angry.

poetryblock.poem: If only there were thorns and briars for me to battle,
I would trample them
and burn them to the ground.

poem.verse: 5Or let it take hold of my strength;

poetryblock.poem: let it make peace with me –
make peace with me.

poem.verse: 6In days to come, Jacob will take root.

poetryblock.poem: Israel will blossom and bloom
and fill the whole world with fruit.

poem.verse: 7Did the Lord strike Israel

poetryblock.poem: as he struck the one who struck Israel?
Was Israel killed like those killed by the Lord?

poem.verse: 8You disputed with Israel

poetryblock.poem: by banishing and driving her away.
He removed her with his severe storm
on the day of the east wind.
