poem.verse: 9Therefore Jacob’s iniquity will be atoned for in this way,

poetryblock.poem: and the result of the removal of his sin will be this:
when he makes all the altar stones
like crushed bits of chalk,
no Asherah poles or incense altars will remain standing.

poem.verse: 10For the fortified city will be desolate,

poetryblock.poem: pastures deserted and abandoned like a wilderness.
Calves will graze there,
and there they will spread out and strip its branches.

poem.verse: 11When its branches dry out, they will be broken off.

poetryblock.poem: Women will come and make fires with them,
for they are not a people with understanding.
Therefore their Maker will not have compassion on them,
and their Creator will not be gracious to them.

poem.verse: 12On that day

poetryblock.poem: the Lord will thresh corn from the River Euphrates
as far as the Wadi of Egypt,
and you Israelites will be gathered one by one.

poem.verse: 13On that day

poetryblock.poem: a great ram’s horn will be blown,
and those lost in the land of Assyria will come,
as well as those dispersed in the land of Egypt;
and they will worship the Lord
at Jerusalem on the holy mountain.

poem.verse: 1Woe to the majestic crown of Ephraim’s drunkards,

poetryblock.poem: and to the fading flower of its beautiful splendour,
which is on the summit above the rich valley.
Woe to those overcome with wine.

poem.verse: 2Look, the Lord has a strong and mighty one –

poetryblock.poem: like a devastating hailstorm,
like a storm with strong flooding water.
He will bring it across the land with his hand.

poem.verse: 3The majestic crown of Ephraim’s drunkards

poetryblock.poem: will be trampled underfoot.

poem.verse: 4The fading flower of his beautiful splendour,

poetryblock.poem: which is on the summit above the rich valley,
will be like a ripe fig before the summer harvest.
Whoever sees it will swallow it
while it is still in his hand.

poem.verse: 5On that day

poetryblock.poem: the Lord of Armies will become a crown of beauty
and a diadem of splendour
to the remnant of his people,

poem.verse: 6a spirit of justice

poetryblock.poem: to the one who sits in judgement,
and strength
to those who repel attacks at the city gate.

poem.verse: 7Even these stagger because of wine

poetryblock.poem: and stumble under the influence of beer:
Priest and prophet stagger because of beer.
They are confused by wine.
They stumble because of beer.
They are muddled in their visions.
They stumble in their judgements.

poem.verse: 8Indeed, all their tables are covered with vomit;

poetryblock.poem: there is no place without a stench.

poem.verse: 9Who is he trying to teach?

poetryblock.poem: Who is he trying to instruct?
Infants just weaned from milk?
Babies removed from the breast?

poem.verse: 10‘Law after law, law after law,

poetryblock.poem: line after line, line after line,
a little here, a little there.’

poem.verse: 11For he will speak to this people

poetryblock.poem: with stammering speech
and in a foreign language.

poem.verse: 12He had said to them,

poetryblock.poem: ‘This is the place of rest;
let the weary rest;
this is the place of repose.’
But they would not listen.

poem.verse: 13The word of the Lord will come to them:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Law after law, law after law,
line after line, line after line,
a little here, a little there,’
so they go stumbling backwards,
to be broken, trapped, and captured.

poem.verse: 14Therefore hear the word of the Lord, you scoffers

poetryblock.poem: who rule this people in Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 15For you said, ‘We have made a covenant with Death,

poetryblock.poem: and we have an agreement with Sheol;
when the overwhelming catastrophe passes through,
it will not touch us,
because we have made falsehood our refuge
and have hidden behind treachery.’

poem.verse: 16Therefore the Lord God said:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Look, I have laid a stone in Zion,
a tested stone,
a precious cornerstone, a sure foundation;
the one who believes will be unshakable.

poem.verse: 17And I will make justice the measuring line

poetryblock.poem: and righteousness the mason’s level.’
Hail will sweep away the false refuge,
and water will flood your hiding place.

poem.verse: 18Your covenant with Death will be dissolved,

poetryblock.poem: and your agreement with Sheol will not last.
When the overwhelming catastrophe passes through,
you will be trampled.

poem.verse: 19Every time it passes through,

poetryblock.poem: it will carry you away;
it will pass through every morning –
every day and every night.
Only terror will cause you
to understand the message.

poem.verse: 20Indeed, the bed is too short to stretch out on,

poetryblock.poem: and its cover too small to wrap up in.

poem.verse: 21For the Lord will rise up as he did at Mount Perazim.

poetryblock.poem: He will rise in wrath, as at the Valley of Gibeon,
to do his work, his unexpected work,
and to perform his task, his unfamiliar task.

poem.verse: 22So now, do not scoff,

poetryblock.poem: or your shackles will become stronger.
Indeed, I have heard from the Lord God of Armies
a decree of destruction for the whole land.

poem.verse: 23Listen and hear my voice.

poetryblock.poem: Pay attention and hear what I say.

poem.verse: 24Does the ploughman plough every day to plant seed?

poetryblock.poem: Does he continuously break up and cultivate the soil?

poem.verse: 25When he has levelled its surface,

poetryblock.poem: does he not then scatter black cumin and sow cumin?
He plants wheat in rows and barley in plots,
with spelt as their border.

poem.verse: 26His God teaches him order;

poetryblock.poem: he instructs him.

poem.verse: 27Certainly black cumin is not threshed

poetryblock.poem: with a threshing board,
and a cartwheel is not rolled over the cumin.
But black cumin is beaten out with a stick,
and cumin with a rod.

poem.verse: 28Bread grain is crushed,

poetryblock.poem: but is not threshed endlessly.
Though the wheel of the farmer’s cart rumbles,
his horses do not crush it.

poem.verse: 29This also comes from the Lord of Armies.

poetryblock.poem: He gives wondrous advice;
he gives great wisdom.

poem.verse: 1Woe to Ariel, Ariel,

poetryblock.poem: the city where David camped!
Continue year after year;
let the festivals recur.

poem.verse: 2I will oppress Ariel,

poetryblock.poem: and there will be mourning and crying,
and she will be to me like an Ariel.

poem.verse: 3I will camp in a circle round you;

poetryblock.poem: I will besiege you with earth ramps,
and I will set up my siege towers against you.

poem.verse: 4You will be brought down;

poetryblock.poem: you will speak from the ground,
and your words will come from low in the dust.
Your voice will be like that of a spirit from the ground;
your speech will whisper from the dust.

poem.verse: 5Your many foes will be like fine dust,

poetryblock.poem: and many of the ruthless, like blowing chaff.
Then suddenly, in an instant,

poem.verse: 6you will be punished by the Lord of Armies

poetryblock.poem: with thunder, earthquake, and loud noise,
storm, tempest, and a flame of consuming fire.

poem.verse: 7All the many nations

poetryblock.poem: going out to battle against Ariel –
all the attackers, the siege works against her,
and those who oppress her –
will then be like a dream, a vision in the night.

poem.verse: 8It will be like a hungry one who dreams he is eating,

poetryblock.poem: then wakes and is still hungry;
and like a thirsty one who dreams he is drinking,
then wakes and is still thirsty, longing for water.
So it will be for all the many nations
who go to battle against Mount Zion.

poem.verse: 9Stop and be astonished;

poetryblock.poem: blind yourselves and be blind!
They are drunk, but not with wine;
they stagger, but not with beer.

poem.verse: 10For the Lord has poured out on you

poetryblock.poem: an overwhelming urge to sleep;
he has shut your eyes (the prophets)
and covered your heads (the seers).

p.verse: 11For you the entire vision will be like the words of a sealed document. If it is given to one who can read and he is asked to read it, he will say, ‘I can’t read it, because it is sealed.’
12And if the document is given to one who cannot read and he is asked to read it, he will say, ‘I can’t read.’
13The Lord said:

poetryblock.poem: These people approach me with their speeches
to honour me with lip-service,
yet their hearts are far from me,
and human rules direct their worship of me.

poem.verse: 14Therefore, I will again confound these people

poetryblock.poem: with wonder after wonder.
The wisdom of their wise will vanish,
and the perception of their perceptive will be hidden.

poem.verse: 15Woe to those who go to great lengths

poetryblock.poem: to hide their plans from the Lord.
They do their works in the dark,
and say, ‘Who sees us? Who knows us? ’

poem.verse: 16You have turned things around,

poetryblock.poem: as if the potter were the same as the clay.
How can what is made say about its maker,
‘He didn’t make me’?
How can what is formed
say about the one who formed it,
‘He doesn’t understand what he’s doing’?

poem.verse: 17Isn’t it true that in just a little while

poetryblock.poem: Lebanon will become an orchard,
and the orchard will seem like a forest?

poem.verse: 18On that day the deaf will hear

poetryblock.poem: the words of a document,
and out of a deep darkness
the eyes of the blind will see.

poem.verse: 19The humble will have joy

poetryblock.poem: after joy in the Lord,
and the poor people will rejoice
in the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 20For the ruthless one will vanish,

poetryblock.poem: the scorner will disappear,
and all those who lie in wait with evil intent
will be killed –

poem.verse: 21those who, with their speech,

poetryblock.poem: accuse a person of wrongdoing,
who set a trap for the one mediating at the city gate
and without cause deprive the righteous of justice.

p.verse: 22Therefore, the Lord who redeemed Abraham says this about the house of Jacob:

poetryblock.poem: Jacob will no longer be ashamed,
and his face will no longer be pale.

poem.verse: 23For when he sees his children,

poetryblock.poem: the work of my hands within his nation,
they will honour my name,
they will honour the Holy One of Jacob
and stand in awe of the God of Israel.

poem.verse: 24Those who are confused will gain understanding,

poetryblock.poem: and those who grumble will accept instruction.

poem.verse: 1Woe to the rebellious children!

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
They carry out a plan, but not mine;
they make an alliance,
but against my will,
piling sin on top of sin.

poem.verse: 2Without asking my advice

poetryblock.poem: they set out to go down to Egypt
in order to seek shelter under Pharaoh’s protection
and take refuge in Egypt’s shadow.

poem.verse: 3But Pharaoh’s protection will become your shame,

poetryblock.poem: and refuge in Egypt’s shadow your humiliation.

poem.verse: 4For though his princes are at Zoan

poetryblock.poem: and his messengers reach as far as Hanes,

poem.verse: 5everyone will be ashamed

poetryblock.poem: because of a people who can’t help.
They are of no benefit, they are no help;
they are good for nothing but shame and disgrace.

p.verse: 6A pronouncement concerning the animals of the Negev:

poetryblock.poem: Through a land of trouble and distress,
of lioness and lion,
of viper and flying serpent,
they carry their wealth on the backs of donkeys
and their treasures on the humps of camels,
to a people who will not help them.

poem.verse: 7Egypt’s help is completely worthless;

poetryblock.poem: therefore, I call her:
Rahab Who Just Sits.

poem.verse: 8Go now, write it on a tablet in their presence

poetryblock.poem: and inscribe it on a scroll;
it will be for the future,
for ever and ever.

poem.verse: 9They are a rebellious people,

poetryblock.poem: deceptive children,
children who do not want to listen to the Lord’s instruction.

poem.verse: 10They say to the seers, ‘Do not see,’

poetryblock.poem: and to the prophets,
‘Do not prophesy the truth to us.
Tell us flattering things.
Prophesy illusions.

poem.verse: 11Get out of the way!

poetryblock.poem: Leave the pathway.
Rid us of the Holy One of Israel.’

poem.verse: 12Therefore the Holy One of Israel says:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Because you have rejected this message
and have trusted in oppression and deceit,
and have depended on them,

poem.verse: 13this iniquity of yours will be

poetryblock.poem: like a crumbling gap,
a bulge in a high wall
whose collapse will come in an instant ​– ​suddenly!

poem.verse: 14Its collapse will be like the shattering

poetryblock.poem: of a potter’s jar, crushed to pieces,
so that not even a fragment of pottery
will be found among its shattered remains –
no fragment large enough to take fire from a hearth
or scoop water from a cistern.’

poem.verse: 15For the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel, has said:

poetryblock.poem: ‘You will be delivered by returning and resting;
your strength will lie in quiet confidence.
But you are not willing.’

poem.verse: 16You say, ‘No!

poetryblock.poem: We will escape on horses’ –
therefore you will escape! –
and, ‘We will ride on fast horses’ –
but those who pursue you will be faster.

poem.verse: 17One thousand will flee at the threat of one,

poetryblock.poem: at the threat of five you will flee,
until you remain
like a solitary pole on a mountaintop
or a banner on a hill.

poem.verse: 18Therefore the Lord is waiting to show you mercy,

poetryblock.poem: and is rising up to show you compassion,
for the Lord is a just God.
All who wait patiently for him are happy.

p.verse: 19For people will live on Zion in Jerusalem. You will never weep again; he will show favour to you at the sound of your outcry; as soon as he hears, he will answer you.
20The Lord will give you meagre bread and water during oppression, but your Teacher will not hide any longer. Your eyes will see your Teacher,
21and whenever you turn to the right or to the left, your ears will hear this command behind you: ‘This is the way. Walk in it.’
22Then you will defile your silver-plated idols and your gold-plated images. You will throw them away like menstrual cloths, and call them filth.
23Then he will send rain for your seed that you have sown in the ground, and the food, the produce of the ground, will be rich and plentiful. On that day your cattle will graze in open pastures.
24The oxen and donkeys that work the ground will eat salted fodder scattered with winnowing shovel and fork.
25Streams flowing with water will be on every high mountain and every raised hill on the day of great slaughter when the towers fall.

26The moonlight will be as bright as the sunlight, and the sunlight will be seven times brighter ​– ​like the light of seven days ​– ​on the day that the Lord bandages his people’s injuries and heals the wounds he inflicted.

poem.verse: 27Look! The name of the Lord is coming from far away,

poetryblock.poem: his anger burning and heavy with smoke.
His lips are full of fury,
and his tongue is like a consuming fire.

poem.verse: 28His breath is like an overflowing torrent

poetryblock.poem: that rises to the neck.
He comes to sift the nations in a sieve of destruction
and to put a bridle on the jaws of the peoples
to lead them astray.

poem.verse: 29Your singing will be like that

poetryblock.poem: on the night of a holy festival,
and your heart will rejoice
like one who walks to the music of a flute,
going up to the mountain of the Lord,
to the Rock of Israel.

poem.verse: 30And the Lord will make the splendour of his voice heard

poetryblock.poem: and reveal his arm striking in angry wrath
and a flame of consuming fire,
in driving rain, a torrent, and hailstones.

poem.verse: 31Assyria will be shattered by the voice of the Lord.

poetryblock.poem: He will strike with a rod.

poem.verse: 32And every stroke of the appointed staff

poetryblock.poem: that the Lord brings down on him
will be to the sound of tambourines and lyres;
he will fight against him with brandished weapons.

poem.verse: 33Indeed! Topheth has been ready

poetryblock.poem: for the king for a long time.
Its funeral pyre is deep and wide,
with plenty of fire and wood.
The breath of the Lord, like a torrent of burning sulphur,
kindles it.

poem.verse: 1Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help

poetryblock.poem: and who depend on horses!
They trust in the abundance of chariots
and in the large number of horsemen.
They do not look to the Holy One of Israel,
and they do not seek the Lord.

poem.verse: 2But he also is wise and brings disaster.

poetryblock.poem: He does not go back on what he says;
he will rise up against the house of the wicked
and against the allies of evildoers.

poem.verse: 3Egyptians are men, not God;

poetryblock.poem: their horses are flesh, not spirit.
When the Lord raises his hand to strike,
the helper will stumble
and the one who is helped will fall;
both will perish together.

p.verse: 4For this is what the Lord said to me:

poetryblock.poem: As a lion or young lion growls over its prey
when a band of shepherds is called out against it,
and it is not terrified by their shouting
or subdued by their noise,
so the Lord of Armies will come down
to fight on Mount Zion
and on its hill.

poem.verse: 5Like hovering birds,

poetryblock.poem: so the Lord of Armies will protect Jerusalem;
by protecting it, he will rescue it;
by passing over it, he will deliver it.

p.verse: 6Return to the one the Israelites have greatly rebelled against.
7For on that day, every one of you will reject the worthless idols of silver and gold that your own hands have sinfully made.

poem.verse: 8Then Assyria will fall,

poetryblock.poem: but not by human sword;
a sword will devour him,
but not one made by man.
He will flee from the sword;
his young men will be put to forced labour.

poem.verse: 9His rock will pass away because of fear,

poetryblock.poem: and his officers will be afraid because of the signal flag.

chapter.p: This is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​whose fire is in Zion and whose furnace is in Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 1Indeed, a king will reign righteously,

poetryblock.poem: and rulers will rule justly.

poem.verse: 2Each will be like a shelter from the wind,

poetryblock.poem: a refuge from the rain,
like flowing streams in a dry land
and the shade of a massive rock in an arid land.

poem.verse: 3Then the eyes of those who see will not be closed,

poetryblock.poem: and the ears of those who hear will listen.

poem.verse: 4The reckless mind will gain knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: and the stammering tongue will speak clearly and fluently.

poem.verse: 5A fool will no longer be called a noble,

poetryblock.poem: nor a scoundrel said to be important.

poem.verse: 6For a fool speaks foolishness

poetryblock.poem: and his mind plots iniquity.
He lives in a godless way
and speaks falsely about the Lord.
He leaves the hungry empty
and deprives the thirsty of drink.

poem.verse: 7The scoundrel’s weapons are destructive;

poetryblock.poem: he hatches plots to destroy the needy with lies,
even when the poor person says what is right.

poem.verse: 8But a noble person plans noble things;

poetryblock.poem: he stands up for noble causes.

poem.verse: 9Stand up, you complacent women;

poetryblock.poem: listen to me.
Pay attention to what I say,
you overconfident daughters.

poem.verse: 10In a little more than a year

poetryblock.poem: you overconfident ones will shudder,
for the grapes will fail
and the harvest will not come.

poem.verse: 11Shudder, you complacent ones;

poetryblock.poem: tremble, you overconfident ones!
Strip yourselves bare
and put sackcloth round your waists.

poem.verse: 12Beat your breasts in mourning

poetryblock.poem: for the delightful fields and the fruitful vines,

poem.verse: 13for the ground of my people

poetryblock.poem: growing thorns and briars,
indeed, for every joyous house in the jubilant city.

poem.verse: 14For the palace will be deserted,

poetryblock.poem: the busy city abandoned.
The hill and the watchtower will become
barren places for ever,
the joy of wild donkeys,
and a pasture for flocks,

poem.verse: 15until the Spirit from on high is poured out on us.

poetryblock.poem: Then the desert will become an orchard,
and the orchard will seem like a forest.

poem.verse: 16Then justice will inhabit the wilderness,

poetryblock.poem: and righteousness will dwell in the orchard.

poem.verse: 17The result of righteousness will be peace;

poetryblock.poem: the effect of righteousness
will be quiet confidence for ever.

poem.verse: 18Then my people will dwell in a peaceful place,

poetryblock.poem: in safe and secure dwellings.

poem.verse: 19But hail will level the forest,

poetryblock.poem: and the city will sink into the depths.

poem.verse: 20You will be happy as you sow seed

poetryblock.poem: beside abundant water,
and as you let oxen and donkeys range freely.

poem.verse: 1Woe, you destroyer never destroyed,

poetryblock.poem: you traitor never betrayed!
When you have finished destroying,
you will be destroyed.
When you have finished betraying,
they will betray you.

poem.verse: 2Lord, be gracious to us! We wait for you.

poetryblock.poem: Be our strength every morning
and our salvation in time of trouble.

poem.verse: 3The peoples flee at the thunderous noise;

poetryblock.poem: the nations scatter when you rise in your majesty.

poem.verse: 4Your spoil will be gathered as locusts are gathered;

poetryblock.poem: people will swarm over it like an infestation of locusts.

poem.verse: 5The Lord is exalted, for he dwells on high;

poetryblock.poem: he has filled Zion with justice and righteousness.

poem.verse: 6There will be times of security for you –

poetryblock.poem: a storehouse of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge.
The fear of the Lord is Zion’s treasure.

poem.verse: 7Listen! Their warriors cry loudly in the streets;

poetryblock.poem: the messengers of peace weep bitterly.

poem.verse: 8The roads are deserted;

poetryblock.poem: travel has ceased.
An agreement has been broken,
cities despised,
and human life disregarded.

poem.verse: 9The land mourns and withers;

poetryblock.poem: Lebanon is ashamed and wilted.
Sharon is like a desert;
Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves.

poem.verse: 10‘Now I will rise up,’ says the Lord.

poetryblock.poem: ‘Now I will lift myself up.
Now I will be exalted.

poem.verse: 11You will conceive chaff;

poetryblock.poem: you will give birth to stubble.
Your breath is fire that will consume you.

poem.verse: 12The peoples will be burned to ashes,

poetryblock.poem: like thorns cut down and burned in a fire.

poem.verse: 13You who are far off, hear what I have done;

poetryblock.poem: you who are near, know my strength.’

poem.verse: 14The sinners in Zion are afraid;

poetryblock.poem: trembling seizes the ungodly:
‘Who among us can dwell with a consuming fire?
Who among us can dwell with ever-burning flames? ’

poem.verse: 15The one who lives righteously

poetryblock.poem: and speaks rightly,
who refuses profit from extortion,
whose hand never takes a bribe,
who stops his ears from listening to murderous plots
and shuts his eyes against evil schemes –

poem.verse: 16he will dwell on the heights;

poetryblock.poem: his refuge will be the rocky fortresses,
his food provided, his water assured.

poem.verse: 17Your eyes will see the King in his beauty;

poetryblock.poem: you will see a vast land.

poem.verse: 18Your mind will meditate on the past terror:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Where is the accountant?
Where is the tribute collector?
Where is the one who spied out our defences? ’

poem.verse: 19You will no longer see the barbarians,

poetryblock.poem: a people whose speech is difficult to comprehend –
who stammer in a language that is not understood.

poem.verse: 20Look at Zion, the city of our festival times.

poetryblock.poem: Your eyes will see Jerusalem,
a peaceful pasture, a tent that does not wander;
its tent pegs will not be pulled up
nor will any of its cords be loosened.

poem.verse: 21For the majestic one, our Lord, will be there,

poetryblock.poem: a place of rivers and broad streams
where ships that are rowed will not go,
and majestic vessels will not pass.

poem.verse: 22For the Lord is our Judge,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord is our Lawgiver,
the Lord is our King.
He will save us.

poem.verse: 23Your ropes are slack;

poetryblock.poem: they cannot hold the base of the mast
or spread out the flag.
Then abundant spoil will be divided,
the lame will plunder it,

poem.verse: 24and none there will say, ‘I am ill.’

poetryblock.poem: The people who dwell there
will be forgiven their iniquity.

poem.verse: 1You nations, come here and listen;

poetryblock.poem: you peoples, pay attention!
Let the earth and all that fills it hear,
the world and all that comes from it.

poem.verse: 2The Lord is angry with all the nations,

poetryblock.poem: furious with all their armies.
He will set them apart for destruction,
giving them over to slaughter.

poem.verse: 3Their slain will be thrown out,

poetryblock.poem: and the stench of their corpses will rise;
the mountains will flow with their blood.

poem.verse: 4All the stars in the sky will dissolve.

poetryblock.poem: The sky will roll up like a scroll,
and its stars will all wither
as leaves wither on the vine,
and foliage on the fig tree.

poem.verse: 5When my sword has drunk its fill in the heavens,

poetryblock.poem: it will then come down on Edom
and on the people I have set apart for destruction.

poem.verse: 6The Lord’s sword is covered with blood.

poetryblock.poem: It drips with fat,
with the blood of lambs and goats,
with the fat of the kidneys of rams.
For the Lord has a sacrifice in Bozrah,
a great slaughter in the land of Edom.

poem.verse: 7The wild oxen will be struck down with them,

poetryblock.poem: and young bulls with the mighty bulls.
Their land will be soaked with blood,
and their soil will be saturated with fat.

poem.verse: 8For the Lord has a day of vengeance,

poetryblock.poem: a time of paying back Edom
for its hostility against Zion.

poem.verse: 9Edom’s streams will be turned into pitch,

poetryblock.poem: her soil into sulphur;
her land will become burning pitch.

poem.verse: 10It will never go out ​– ​day or night.

poetryblock.poem: Its smoke will go up for ever.
It will be desolate, from generation to generation;
no one will pass through it for ever and ever.

poem.verse: 11Eagle owls and herons will possess it,

poetryblock.poem: and long-eared owls and ravens will dwell there.
The Lord will stretch out a measuring line
and a plumb line over her
for her destruction and chaos.

poem.verse: 12No nobles will be left to proclaim a king,

poetryblock.poem: and all her princes will come to nothing.

poem.verse: 13Her palaces will be overgrown with thorns;

poetryblock.poem: her fortified cities, with thistles and briars.
She will become a dwelling for jackals,
an abode for ostriches.

poem.verse: 14The desert creatures will meet hyenas,

poetryblock.poem: and one wild goat will call to another.
Indeed, the night birds will stay there
and will find a resting place.

poem.verse: 15Sand partridges will make their nests there;

poetryblock.poem: they will lay and hatch their eggs
and will gather their broods under their shadows.
Indeed, the birds of prey will gather there,
each with its mate.

poem.verse: 16Search and read the scroll of the Lord:

poetryblock.poem: Not one of them will be missing,
none will be lacking its mate,
because he has ordered it by my mouth,
and he will gather them by his Spirit.

poem.verse: 17He has cast the lot for them;

poetryblock.poem: his hand allotted their portion with a measuring line.
They will possess it for ever;
they will dwell in it from generation to generation.

poem.verse: 1The wilderness and the dry land will be glad;

poetryblock.poem: the desert will rejoice and blossom like a wildflower.

poem.verse: 2It will blossom abundantly

poetryblock.poem: and will also rejoice with joy and singing.
The glory of Lebanon will be given to it,
the splendour of Carmel and Sharon.
They will see the glory of the Lord,
the splendour of our God.

poem.verse: 3Strengthen the weak hands,

poetryblock.poem: steady the shaking knees!

poem.verse: 4Say to the cowardly:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Be strong; do not fear!
Here is your God; vengeance is coming.
God’s retribution is coming; he will save you.’

poem.verse: 5Then the eyes of the blind will be opened,

poetryblock.poem: and the ears of the deaf unstopped.

poem.verse: 6Then the lame will leap like a deer,

poetryblock.poem: and the tongue of the mute will sing for joy,
for water will gush in the wilderness,
and streams in the desert;

poem.verse: 7the parched ground will become a pool,

poetryblock.poem: and the thirsty land, springs.
In the haunt of jackals, in their lairs,
there will be grass, reeds, and papyrus.

poem.verse: 8A road will be there and a way;

poetryblock.poem: it will be called the Holy Way.
The unclean will not travel on it,
but it will be for the one who walks the path.
Fools will not wander on it.

poem.verse: 9There will be no lion there,

poetryblock.poem: and no vicious beast will go up on it;
they will not be found there.
But the redeemed will walk on it,

poem.verse: 10and the ransomed of the Lord will return

poetryblock.poem: and come to Zion with singing,
crowned with unending joy.
Joy and gladness will overtake them,
and sorrow and sighing will flee.

p.verse: 1In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria attacked all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

2Then the king of Assyria sent his royal spokesman, along with a massive army, from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. The Assyrian stood near the conduit of the upper pool, by the road to Launderer’s Field.
3Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the court secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the court historian, came out to him.
4The royal spokesman said to them, ‘Tell Hezekiah:

blockindent.p: The great king, the king of Assyria, says this: What are you relying on? 5You think mere words are strategy and strength for war. Who are you now relying on that you have rebelled against me?6Look, you are relying on Egypt, that splintered reed of a staff that will pierce the hand of anyone who grabs it and leans on it. This is how Pharaoh king of Egypt is to all who rely on him.7Suppose you say to me, “We rely on the Lord our God.” Isn’t he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and Jerusalem, “You are to worship at this altar”?

p.verse: 8‘Now make a deal with my master, the king of Assyria. I’ll give you two thousand horses if you’re able to supply riders for them!
9How then can you drive back a single officer among the least of my master’s servants? How can you rely on Egypt for chariots and horsemen?
10Have I attacked this land to destroy it without the Lord’s approval? The Lord said to me, “Attack this land and destroy it.” ’

11Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the royal spokesman, ‘Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, since we understand it. Don’t speak to us in Hebrew within earshot of the people who are on the wall.’

12But the royal spokesman replied, ‘Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you, and not to the men who are sitting on the wall, who are destined with you to eat their own excrement and drink their own urine? ’
13Then the royal spokesman stood and called out loudly in Hebrew:

blockindent.p: Listen to the words of the great king, the king of Assyria! 14This is what the king says: ‘Don’t let Hezekiah deceive you, for he cannot rescue you.15Don’t let Hezekiah persuade you to rely on the Lord, saying, “The Lord will certainly rescue us! This city will not be handed over to the king of Assyria.” ’

p.verse: 16Don’t listen to Hezekiah, for this is what the king of Assyria says: ‘Make peace with me and surrender to me. Then every one of you may eat from his own vine and his own fig tree and drink water from his own cistern
17until I come and take you away to a land like your own land ​– ​a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.
18Beware that Hezekiah does not mislead you by saying, “The Lord will rescue us.” Has any one of the gods of the nations rescued his land from the power of the king of Assyria?
19Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they rescued Samaria from my power?
20Who among all the gods of these lands ever rescued his land from my power? So will the Lord rescue Jerusalem from my power? ’
21But they kept silent; they didn’t say anything, for the king’s command was, ‘Don’t answer him.’

22Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the court secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the court historian, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and reported to him the words of the royal spokesman.
1When King Hezekiah heard their report, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went to the Lord’s temple.
2He sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the court secretary, and the leading priests, who were covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.
3They said to him, ‘This is what Hezekiah says: “Today is a day of distress, rebuke, and disgrace. It is as if children have come to the point of birth, and there is no strength to deliver them.

4Perhaps the Lord your God will hear all the words of the royal spokesman, whom his master the king of Assyria sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke him for the words that the Lord your God has heard. Therefore offer a prayer for the surviving remnant.” ’
5So the servants of King Hezekiah went to Isaiah,
6who said to them, ‘Tell your master, “The Lord says this: Don’t be afraid because of the words you have heard, with which the king of Assyria’s attendants have blasphemed me.
7I am about to put a spirit in him and he will hear a rumour and return to his own land, where I will cause him to fall by the sword.” ’
8When the royal spokesman heard that the king of Assyria had pulled out of Lachish, he left and found him fighting against Libnah.
9The king had heard concerning King Tirhakah of Cush, ‘He has set out to fight against you.’ So when he heard this, he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
10‘Say this to King Hezekiah of Judah: “Don’t let your God, on whom you rely, deceive you by promising that Jerusalem won’t be handed over to the king of Assyria.
11Look, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the countries: they completely destroyed them. Will you be rescued?
12Did the gods of the nations that my predecessors destroyed rescue them ​– ​Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the Edenites in Telassar?
13Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, Hena, or Ivvah? ” ’
14Hezekiah took the letter from the messengers’ hands, read it, then went up to the Lord’s temple and spread it out before the Lord.
15Then Hezekiah prayed to the Lord:
16Lord of Armies, God of Israel, enthroned between the cherubim, you are God ​– ​you alone ​– ​of all the kingdoms of the earth. You made the heavens and the earth.
17Listen closely, Lord, and hear; open your eyes, Lord, and see. Hear all the words that Sennacherib has sent to mock the living God.
18Lord, it is true that the kings of Assyria have devastated all these countries and their lands.
19They have thrown their gods into the fire, for they were not gods but made from wood and stone by human hands. So they have destroyed them.
20Now, Lord our God, save us from his power so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you, Lord, are God ​– ​you alone.
21Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent a message to Hezekiah: ‘The Lord, the God of Israel, says, “Because you prayed to me about King Sennacherib of Assyria,
22this is the word the Lord has spoken against him:

poetryblock.poem: Virgin Daughter Zion
despises you and scorns you;
Daughter Jerusalem shakes her head
behind your back.

poem.verse: 23Who is it you have mocked and blasphemed?

poetryblock.poem: Against whom have you raised your voice
and lifted your eyes in pride?
Against the Holy One of Israel!

poem.verse: 24You have mocked the Lord through your servants.

poetryblock.poem: You have said, ‘With my many chariots
I have gone up to the heights of the mountains,
to the far recesses of Lebanon.
I cut down its tallest cedars,
its choice cypress trees.
I came to its distant heights,
its densest forest.

poem.verse: 25I dug wells and drank water in foreign lands.

poetryblock.poem: I dried up all the streams of Egypt
with the soles of my feet.’

poem.verse: 26Have you not heard?

poetryblock.poem: I designed it long ago;
I planned it in days gone by.
I have now brought it to pass,
and you have crushed fortified cities
into piles of rubble.

poem.verse: 27Their inhabitants have become powerless,

poetryblock.poem: dismayed, and ashamed.
They are plants of the field,
tender grass,
grass on the rooftops,
blasted by the east wind.

poem.verse: 28But I know your sitting down,

poetryblock.poem: your going out and your coming in,
and your raging against me.

poem.verse: 29Because your raging against me

poetryblock.poem: and your arrogance have reached my ears,
I will put my hook in your nose
and my bit in your mouth;
I will make you go back
the way you came.

p.verse: 30‘ “This will be the sign for you: This year you will eat what grows on its own, and in the second year what grows from that. But in the third year sow and reap, plant vineyards and eat their fruit.
31The surviving remnant of the house of Judah will again take root downwards and bear fruit upwards.
32For a remnant will go out from Jerusalem, and survivors from Mount Zion. The zeal of the Lord of Armies will accomplish this.”
33‘Therefore, this is what the Lord says about the king of Assyria:

poetryblock.poem: He will not enter this city,
shoot an arrow here,
come before it with a shield,
or build up a siege ramp against it.

poem.verse: 34He will go back

poetryblock.poem: the way he came,
and he will not enter this city.

poem.verse: 35I will defend this city and rescue it

poetryblock.poem: for my sake
and for the sake of my servant David.’

p.verse: 36Then the angel of the Lord went out and struck down one hundred and eighty-five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians. When the people got up the next morning, there were all the dead bodies!
37So King Sennacherib of Assyria broke camp and left. He returned home and lived in Nineveh.

38One day, while he was worshipping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer struck him down with the sword and escaped to the land of Ararat. Then his son Esar-haddon became king in his place.

1In those days Hezekiah became terminally ill. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came and said to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Set your house in order, for you are about to die; you will not recover.” ’
2Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord.
3He said, ‘Please, Lord, remember how I have walked before you faithfully and wholeheartedly, and have done what pleases you.’ And Hezekiah wept bitterly.
4Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah:
5‘Go and tell Hezekiah, “This is what the Lord God of your ancestor David says: I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears. Look, I am going to add fifteen years to your life.
6And I will rescue you and this city from the grasp of the king of Assyria; I will defend this city.
7This is the sign to you from the Lord that he will do what he has promised:
8I am going to make the sun’s shadow that goes down on the stairway of Ahaz go back by ten steps.” ’ So the sun’s shadow went back the ten steps it had descended.
9A poem by King Hezekiah of Judah after he had been sick and had recovered from his illness:

poem.verse: 10I said: In the prime of my life

poetryblock.poem: I must go to the gates of Sheol;
I am deprived of the rest of my years.

poem.verse: 11I said: I will never see the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord in the land of the living;
I will not look on humanity any longer
with the inhabitants of what is passing away.

poem.verse: 12My dwelling is plucked up and removed from me

poetryblock.poem: like a shepherd’s tent.
I have rolled up my life like a weaver;
he cuts me off from the loom.
By nightfall you make an end of me.

poem.verse: 13I thought until the morning:

poetryblock.poem: He will break all my bones like a lion.
By nightfall you make an end of me.

poem.verse: 14I chirp like a swallow or a crane;

poetryblock.poem: I moan like a dove.
My eyes grow weak looking upwards.
Lord, I am oppressed; support me.

poem.verse: 15What can I say?

poetryblock.poem: He has spoken to me,
and he himself has done it.
I walk along slowly all my years
because of the bitterness of my soul.

poem.verse: 16Lord, by such things people live,

poetryblock.poem: and in every one of them my spirit finds life;
you have restored me to health
and let me live.

poem.verse: 17Indeed, it was for my own well-being

poetryblock.poem: that I had such intense bitterness;
but your love has delivered me
from the Pit of destruction,
for you have thrown all my sins behind your back.

poem.verse: 18For Sheol cannot thank you;

poetryblock.poem: Death cannot praise you.
Those who go down to the Pit
cannot hope for your faithfulness.

poem.verse: 19The living, only the living can thank you,

poetryblock.poem: as I do today;
a father will make your faithfulness known to children.

poem.verse: 20The Lord is ready to save me;

poetryblock.poem: we will play stringed instruments
all the days of our lives
at the house of the Lord.

p.verse: 21Now Isaiah had said, ‘Let them take a lump of pressed figs and apply it to his infected skin, so that he may recover.’
22And Hezekiah had asked, ‘What is the sign that I will go up to the Lord’s temple? ’
1At that time Merodach-baladan son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah since he heard that he had been ill and had recovered.

2Hezekiah was pleased with the letters, and he showed the envoys his treasure-house ​– ​the silver, the gold, the spices, and the precious oil ​– ​and all his armoury, and everything that was found in his treasuries. There was nothing in his palace and in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
3Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and asked him, ‘What did these men say, and where did they come to you from? ’

chapter.p: Hezekiah replied, ‘They came to me from a distant country, from Babylon.’

p.verse: 4Isaiah asked, ‘What have they seen in your palace? ’

chapter.p: Hezekiah answered, ‘They have seen everything in my palace. There isn’t anything in my treasuries that I didn’t show them.’

p.verse: 5Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, ‘Hear the word of the Lord of Armies:
6“Look, the days are coming when everything in your palace and all that your predecessors have stored up until today will be carried off to Babylon; nothing will be left,” says the Lord.
7“Some of your descendants ​– ​who come from you, whom you father ​– ​will be taken away, and they will become eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.” ’
8Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, ‘The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good,’ for he thought: There will be peace and security during my lifetime.

poem.verse: 1‘Comfort, comfort my people,’

poetryblock.poem: says your God.

poem.verse: 2‘Speak tenderly to Jerusalem,

poetryblock.poem: and announce to her
that her time of hard service is over,
her iniquity has been pardoned,
and she has received from the Lord’s hand
double for all her sins.’

p.verse: 3A voice of one crying out:

poetryblock.poem: Prepare the way of the Lord in the wilderness;
make a straight road for our God in the desert.

poem.verse: 4Every valley will be lifted up,

poetryblock.poem: and every mountain and hill will be levelled;
the uneven ground will become smooth
and the rough places, a plain.

poem.verse: 5And the glory of the Lord will appear,

poetryblock.poem: and all humanity together will see it,
for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.

poem.verse: 6A voice was saying, ‘Cry out! ’

poetryblock.poem: Another said, ‘What should I cry out? ’
‘All humanity is grass,
and all its goodness is like the flower of the field.

poem.verse: 7The grass withers, the flowers fade

poetryblock.poem: when the breath of the Lord blows on them;
indeed, the people are grass.

poem.verse: 8The grass withers, the flowers fade,

poetryblock.poem: but the word of our God remains for ever.’

poem.verse: 9Zion, herald of good news,

poetryblock.poem: go up on a high mountain.
Jerusalem, herald of good news,
raise your voice loudly.
Raise it, do not be afraid!
Say to the cities of Judah,
‘Here is your God! ’

poem.verse: 10See, the Lord God comes with strength,

poetryblock.poem: and his power establishes his rule.
His wages are with him,
and his reward accompanies him.

poem.verse: 11He protects his flock like a shepherd;

poetryblock.poem: he gathers the lambs in his arms
and carries them in the fold of his garment.
He gently leads those that are nursing.

poem.verse: 12Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand

poetryblock.poem: or marked off the heavens with the span of his hand?
Who has gathered the dust of the earth in a measure
or weighed the mountains on a balance
and the hills on the scales?

poem.verse: 13Who has instructed the Spirit of the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: or who gave him counsel?

poem.verse: 14Whom did he consult?

poetryblock.poem: Who gave him understanding
and taught him the paths of justice?
Who taught him knowledge
and showed him the way of understanding?

poem.verse: 15Look, the nations are like a drop in a bucket;

poetryblock.poem: they are considered as a speck of dust on the scales;
he lifts up the islands like fine dust.

poem.verse: 16Lebanon’s cedars are not enough for fuel,

poetryblock.poem: or its animals enough for a burnt offering.

poem.verse: 17All the nations are as nothing before him;

poetryblock.poem: they are considered by him
as empty nothingness.

poem.verse: 18With whom will you compare God?

poetryblock.poem: What likeness will you set up for comparison with him?

poem.verse: 19An idol? ​– ​something that a smelter casts

poetryblock.poem: and a metalworker plates with gold
and makes silver chains for?

poem.verse: 20A poor person contributes wood for a pedestal

poetryblock.poem: that will not rot.
He looks for a skilled craftsman
to set up an idol that will not fall over.

poem.verse: 21Do you not know?

poetryblock.poem: Have you not heard?
Has it not been declared to you
from the beginning?
Have you not considered
the foundations of the earth?

poem.verse: 22God is enthroned above the circle of the earth;

poetryblock.poem: its inhabitants are like grasshoppers.
He stretches out the heavens like thin cloth
and spreads them out like a tent to live in.

poem.verse: 23He reduces princes to nothing

poetryblock.poem: and makes judges of the earth like a wasteland.

poem.verse: 24They are barely planted, barely sown,

poetryblock.poem: their stem hardly takes root in the ground
when he blows on them and they wither,
and a whirlwind carries them away like stubble.

poem.verse: 25‘To whom will you compare me,

poetryblock.poem: or who is my equal? ’ asks the Holy One.

poem.verse: 26Look up and see!

poetryblock.poem: Who created these?
He brings out the stars by number;
he calls all of them by name.
Because of his great power and strength,
not one of them is missing.

poem.verse: 27Jacob, why do you say,

poetryblock.poem: and Israel, why do you assert,
‘My way is hidden from the Lord,
and my claim is ignored by my God’?

poem.verse: 28Do you not know?

poetryblock.poem: Have you not heard?
The Lord is the everlasting God,
the Creator of the whole earth.
He never becomes faint or weary;
there is no limit to his understanding.

poem.verse: 29He gives strength to the faint

poetryblock.poem: and strengthens the powerless.

poem.verse: 30Youths may become faint and weary,

poetryblock.poem: and young men stumble and fall,

poem.verse: 31but those who trust in the Lord

poetryblock.poem: will renew their strength;
they will soar on wings like eagles;
they will run and not become weary,
they will walk and not faint.

chapter.head1: The Lord versus the Nations’ Gods

poem.verse: 1‘Be silent before me, coasts and islands!

poetryblock.poem: And let peoples renew their strength.
Let them approach; let them testify;
let’s come together for the trial.

poem.verse: 2Who has stirred up someone from the east?

poetryblock.poem: In righteousness he calls him to serve.
The Lord hands nations over to him,
and he subdues kings.
He makes them like dust with his sword,
like wind-driven stubble with his bow.

poem.verse: 3He pursues them, going on safely,

poetryblock.poem: hardly touching the path with his feet.

poem.verse: 4Who has performed and done this,

poetryblock.poem: calling the generations from the beginning?
I am the Lord, the first
and with the last ​– ​I am he.’

poem.verse: 5The coasts and islands see and are afraid,

poetryblock.poem: the whole earth trembles.
They approach and arrive.

poem.verse: 6Each one helps the other,

poetryblock.poem: and says to another, ‘Take courage! ’

poem.verse: 7The craftsman encourages the metalworker;

poetryblock.poem: the one who flattens with the hammer
encourages the one who strikes the anvil,
saying of the soldering, ‘It is good.’
He fastens it with nails so that it will not fall over.

poem.verse: 8But you, Israel, my servant,

poetryblock.poem: Jacob, whom I have chosen,
descendant of Abraham, my friend –

poem.verse: 9I brought you from the ends of the earth

poetryblock.poem: and called you from its farthest corners.
I said to you: You are my servant;
I have chosen you; I haven’t rejected you.

poem.verse: 10Do not fear, for I am with you;

poetryblock.poem: do not be afraid, for I am your God.
I will strengthen you; I will help you;
I will hold on to you with my righteous right hand.

poem.verse: 11Be sure that all who are enraged against you

poetryblock.poem: will be ashamed and disgraced;
those who contend with you
will become as nothing and will perish.

poem.verse: 12You will look for those who contend with you,

poetryblock.poem: but you will not find them.
Those who war against you
will become absolutely nothing.

poem.verse: 13For I am the Lord your God,

poetryblock.poem: who holds your right hand,
who says to you, ‘Do not fear,
I will help you.

poem.verse: 14Do not fear, you worm Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: you men of Israel.
I will help you’ –
this is the Lord’s declaration.
Your Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 15See, I will make you into a sharp threshing board,

poetryblock.poem: new, with many teeth.
You will thresh mountains and pulverise them
and make hills into chaff.

poem.verse: 16You will winnow them

poetryblock.poem: and a wind will carry them away,
a whirlwind will scatter them.
But you will rejoice in the Lord;
you will boast in the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 17The poor and the needy seek water, but there is none;

poetryblock.poem: their tongues are parched with thirst.
I will answer them.
I am the Lord, the God of Israel. I will not abandon them.

poem.verse: 18I will open rivers on the barren heights,

poetryblock.poem: and springs in the middle of the plains.
I will turn the desert into a pool
and dry land into springs.

poem.verse: 19I will plant cedar, acacia, myrtle, and olive trees

poetryblock.poem: in the wilderness.
I will put juniper, elm, and cypress trees together
in the desert,

poem.verse: 20so that all may see and know,

poetryblock.poem: consider and understand,
that the hand of the Lord has done this,
the Holy One of Israel has created it.

poem.verse: 21‘Submit your case,’ says the Lord.

poetryblock.poem: ‘Present your arguments,’ says Jacob’s King.

poem.verse: 22‘Let them come and tell us

poetryblock.poem: what will happen.
Tell us the past events,
so that we may reflect on them
and know the outcome,
or tell us the future.

poem.verse: 23Tell us the coming events,

poetryblock.poem: then we will know that you are gods.
Indeed, do something good or bad,
then we will be in awe when we see it.

poem.verse: 24Look, you are nothing

poetryblock.poem: and your work is worthless.
Anyone who chooses you is detestable.

poem.verse: 25‘I have stirred up one from the north, and he has come,

poetryblock.poem: one from the east who invokes my name.
He will march over rulers as if they were mud,
like a potter who treads the clay.

poem.verse: 26Who told about this from the beginning,

poetryblock.poem: so that we might know,
and from times past,
so that we might say, “He is right”?
No one announced it,
no one told it,
no one heard your words.

poem.verse: 27I was the first to say to Zion,

poetryblock.poem: “Look! Here they are! ”
And I gave Jerusalem a herald with good news.

poem.verse: 28When I look, there is no one;

poetryblock.poem: there is no counsellor among them;
when I ask them, they have nothing to say.

poem.verse: 29Look, all of them are a delusion;

poetryblock.poem: their works are non-existent;
their images are wind and emptiness.

poem.verse: 1‘This is my servant; I strengthen him,

poetryblock.poem: this is my chosen one; I delight in him.
I have put my Spirit on him;
he will bring justice to the nations.

poem.verse: 2He will not cry out or shout

poetryblock.poem: or make his voice heard in the streets.

poem.verse: 3He will not break a bruised reed,

poetryblock.poem: and he will not put out a smouldering wick;
he will faithfully bring justice.

poem.verse: 4He will not grow weak or be discouraged

poetryblock.poem: until he has established justice on earth.
The coasts and islands will wait for his instruction.’

poem.verse: 5This is what God, the Lord, says –

poetryblock.poem: who created the heavens and stretched them out,
who spread out the earth and what comes from it,
who gives breath to the people on it
and spirit to those who walk on it –

poem.verse: 6‘I am the Lord. I have called you

poetryblock.poem: for a righteous purpose,
and I will hold you by your hand.
I will watch over you, and I will appoint you
to be a covenant for the people
and a light to the nations,

poem.verse: 7in order to open blind eyes,

poetryblock.poem: to bring out prisoners from the dungeon,
and those sitting in darkness from the prison house.

poem.verse: 8I am the Lord. That is my name,

poetryblock.poem: and I will not give my glory to another
or my praise to idols.

poem.verse: 9The past events have indeed happened.

poetryblock.poem: Now I declare new events;
I announce them to you before they occur.’

poem.verse: 10Sing a new song to the Lord;

poetryblock.poem: sing his praise from the ends of the earth,
you who go down to the sea with all that fills it,
you coasts and islands with your inhabitants.

poem.verse: 11Let the desert and its cities shout,

poetryblock.poem: the settlements where Kedar dwells cry aloud.
Let the inhabitants of Sela sing for joy;
let them cry out from the mountaintops.

poem.verse: 12Let them give glory to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: and declare his praise in the coasts and islands.

poem.verse: 13The Lord advances like a warrior;

poetryblock.poem: he stirs up his zeal like a soldier.
He shouts, he roars aloud,
he prevails over his enemies.

poem.verse: 14‘I have kept silent from ages past;

poetryblock.poem: I have been quiet and restrained myself.
But now, I will groan like a woman in labour,
gasping breathlessly.

poem.verse: 15I will lay waste mountains and hills

poetryblock.poem: and dry up all their vegetation.
I will turn rivers into islands
and dry up marshes.

poem.verse: 16I will lead the blind by a way they did not know;

poetryblock.poem: I will guide them on paths they have not known.
I will turn darkness to light in front of them
and rough places into level ground.
This is what I will do for them,
and I will not abandon them.

poem.verse: 17They will be turned back and utterly ashamed –

poetryblock.poem: those who trust in an idol
and say to a cast image,
“You are our gods! ”

poem.verse: 18‘Listen, you deaf!

poetryblock.poem: Look, you blind, so that you may see.

poem.verse: 19Who is blind but my servant,

poetryblock.poem: or deaf like my messenger I am sending?
Who is blind like my dedicated one,
or blind like the servant of the Lord?

poem.verse: 20Though seeing many things, you pay no attention.

poetryblock.poem: Though his ears are open, he does not listen.’

poem.verse: 21Because of his righteousness, the Lord was pleased

poetryblock.poem: to magnify his instruction and make it glorious.

poem.verse: 22But this is a people plundered and looted,

poetryblock.poem: all of them trapped in holes
or imprisoned in dungeons.
They have become plunder
with no one to rescue them
and loot, with no one saying, ‘Give it back! ’

poem.verse: 23Who among you will hear this?

poetryblock.poem: Let him listen and obey in the future.

poem.verse: 24Who gave Jacob to the robber,

poetryblock.poem: and Israel to the plunderers?
Was it not the Lord?
Have we not sinned against him?
They were not willing to walk in his ways,
and they would not listen to his instruction.

poem.verse: 25So he poured out his furious anger

poetryblock.poem: and the power of war on Jacob.
It surrounded him with fire, but he did not know it;
it burned him, but he didn’t take it to heart.

poem.verse: 1Now this is what the Lord says –

poetryblock.poem: the one who created you, Jacob,
and the one who formed you, Israel –
‘Do not fear, for I have redeemed you;
I have called you by your name; you are mine.

poem.verse: 2When you pass through the waters,

poetryblock.poem: I will be with you,
and the rivers will not overwhelm you.
When you walk through the fire,
you will not be scorched,
and the flame will not burn you.

poem.verse: 3For I am the Lord your God,

poetryblock.poem: the Holy One of Israel, and your Saviour.
I have given Egypt as a ransom for you,
Cush and Seba in your place.

poem.verse: 4Because you are precious in my sight

poetryblock.poem: and honoured, and I love you,
I will give people in exchange for you
and nations instead of your life.

poem.verse: 5Do not fear, for I am with you;

poetryblock.poem: I will bring your descendants from the east,
and gather you from the west.

poem.verse: 6I will say to the north, “Give them up! ”

poetryblock.poem: and to the south, “Do not hold them back! ”
Bring my sons from far away,
and my daughters from the ends of the earth –

poem.verse: 7everyone who bears my name

poetryblock.poem: and is created for my glory.
I have formed them; indeed, I have made them.’

poem.verse: 8Bring out a people who are blind, yet have eyes,

poetryblock.poem: and are deaf, yet have ears.

poem.verse: 9All the nations are gathered together,

poetryblock.poem: and the peoples are assembled.
Who among them can declare this,
and tell us the former things?
Let them present their witnesses
to vindicate themselves,
so that people may hear and say, ‘It is true.’

poem.verse: 10‘You are my witnesses’ –

poetryblock.poem: this is the Lord’s declaration –
‘and my servant whom I have chosen,
so that you may know and believe me
and understand that I am he.
No god was formed before me,
and there will be none after me.

poem.verse: 11I ​– ​I am the Lord.

poetryblock.poem: Besides me, there is no Saviour.

poem.verse: 12I alone declared, saved, and proclaimed –

poetryblock.poem: and not some foreign god among you.
So you are my witnesses’ –
this is the Lord’s declaration –
‘and I am God.

poem.verse: 13Also, from today on I am he alone,

poetryblock.poem: and none can rescue from my power.
I act, and who can reverse it? ’

p.verse: 14This is what the Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel says:

poetryblock.poem: Because of you, I will send an army to Babylon
and bring all of them as fugitives,
even the Chaldeans in the ships in which they rejoice.

poem.verse: 15I am the Lord, your Holy One,

poetryblock.poem: the Creator of Israel, your King.

poem.verse: 16This is what the Lord says –

poetryblock.poem: who makes a way in the sea,
and a path through raging water,

poem.verse: 17who brings out the chariot and horse,

poetryblock.poem: the army and the mighty one together
(they lie down, they do not rise again;
they are extinguished, put out like a wick) –

poem.verse: 18‘Do not remember the past events;

poetryblock.poem: pay no attention to things of old.

poem.verse: 19Look, I am about to do something new;

poetryblock.poem: even now it is coming. Do you not see it?
Indeed, I will make a way in the wilderness,
rivers in the desert.

poem.verse: 20Wild animals –

poetryblock.poem: jackals and ostriches ​– ​will honour me,
because I provide water in the wilderness,
and rivers in the desert,
to give drink to my chosen people.

poem.verse: 21The people I formed for myself

poetryblock.poem: will declare my praise.

poem.verse: 22‘But, Jacob, you have not called on me,

poetryblock.poem: because, Israel, you have become weary of me.

poem.verse: 23You have not brought me your sheep for burnt offerings

poetryblock.poem: or honoured me with your sacrifices.
I have not burdened you with offerings
or wearied you with incense.

poem.verse: 24You have not bought me aromatic cane with silver,

poetryblock.poem: or satisfied me with the fat of your sacrifices.
But you have burdened me with your sins;
you have wearied me with your iniquities.

poem.verse: 25‘I am the one, I sweep away your transgressions

poetryblock.poem: for my own sake
and remember your sins no more.

poem.verse: 26Remind me. Let’s argue the case together.

poetryblock.poem: Recount the facts, so that you may be vindicated.

poem.verse: 27Your first father sinned,

poetryblock.poem: and your mediators have rebelled against me.

poem.verse: 28So I defiled the officers of the sanctuary,

poetryblock.poem: and set Jacob apart for destruction
and Israel for scorn.

poem.verse: 1‘And now listen, Jacob my servant,

poetryblock.poem: Israel whom I have chosen.

poem.verse: 2This is the word of the Lord

poetryblock.poem: your Maker, the one who formed you from the womb:
He will help you.
Do not fear, Jacob my servant,
Jeshurun whom I have chosen.

poem.verse: 3For I will pour water on the thirsty land

poetryblock.poem: and streams on the dry ground;
I will pour out my Spirit on your descendants
and my blessing on your offspring.

poem.verse: 4They will sprout among the grass

poetryblock.poem: like poplars by flowing streams.

poem.verse: 5This one will say, “I am the Lord’s”;

poetryblock.poem: another will use the name of Jacob;
still another will write on his hand, “The Lord’s”,
and take on the name of Israel.’

chapter.head1: No God Other Than the Lord

p.verse: 6This is what the Lord, the King of Israel and its Redeemer, the Lord of Armies, says:

poetryblock.poem: I am the first and I am the last.
There is no God but me.

poem.verse: 7Who, like me, can announce the future?

poetryblock.poem: Let him say so and make a case before me,
since I have established an ancient people.
Let these gods declare the coming things,
and what will take place.

poem.verse: 8Do not be startled or afraid.

poetryblock.poem: Have I not told you and declared it long ago?
You are my witnesses!
Is there any God but me?
There is no other Rock; I do not know any.

poem.verse: 9All who make idols are nothing,

poetryblock.poem: and what they treasure benefits no one.
Their witnesses do not see or know anything,
so they will be put to shame.

poem.verse: 10Who makes a god or casts a metal image

poetryblock.poem: that benefits no one?

poem.verse: 11Look, all its worshippers will be put to shame,

poetryblock.poem: and the craftsmen are humans.
They all will assemble and stand;
they all will be startled and put to shame.

poem.verse: 12The ironworker labours over the coals,

poetryblock.poem: shapes the idol with hammers,
and works it with his strong arm.
Also he grows hungry and his strength fails;
he doesn’t drink water and is faint.

poem.verse: 13The woodworker stretches out a measuring line,

poetryblock.poem: he outlines it with a stylus;
he shapes it with chisels
and outlines it with a compass.
He makes it according to a human form,
like a beautiful person,
to dwell in a temple.

poem.verse: 14He cuts down cedars for his use,

poetryblock.poem: or he takes a cypress or an oak.
He lets it grow strong among the trees of the forest.
He plants a laurel, and the rain makes it grow.

poem.verse: 15A person can use it for fuel.

poetryblock.poem: He takes some of it and warms himself;
also he kindles a fire and bakes bread;
he even makes it into a god and worships it;
he makes an idol from it and bows down to it.

poem.verse: 16He burns half of it in a fire,

poetryblock.poem: and he roasts meat on that half.
He eats the roast and is satisfied.
He warms himself and says, ‘Ah!
I am warm, I see the blaze.’

poem.verse: 17He makes a god or his idol with the rest of it.

poetryblock.poem: He bows down to it and worships;
he prays to it, ‘Save me, for you are my god.’

poem.verse: 18Such people do not comprehend

poetryblock.poem: and cannot understand,
for he has shut their eyes so that they cannot see,
and their minds so that they cannot understand.

poem.verse: 19No one comes to his senses;

poetryblock.poem: no one has the perception or insight to say,
‘I burned half of it in the fire,
I also baked bread on its coals,
I roasted meat and ate.
Should I make something detestable with the rest of it?
Should I bow down to a block of wood? ’

poem.verse: 20He feeds on ashes.

poetryblock.poem: His deceived mind has led him astray,
and he cannot rescue himself,
or say, ‘Isn’t there a lie in my right hand? ’

poem.verse: 21Remember these things, Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: and Israel, for you are my servant;
I formed you, you are my servant;
Israel, you will never be forgotten by me.

poem.verse: 22I have swept away your transgressions like a cloud,

poetryblock.poem: and your sins like a mist.
Return to me,
for I have redeemed you.

poem.verse: 23Rejoice, heavens, for the Lord has acted;

poetryblock.poem: shout, depths of the earth.
Break out into singing, mountains,
forest, and every tree in it.
For the Lord has redeemed Jacob,
and glorifies himself through Israel.

p.verse: 24This is what the Lord, your Redeemer who formed you from the womb, says:

poetryblock.poem: I am the Lord, who made everything;
who stretched out the heavens by myself;
who alone spread out the earth;

poem.verse: 25who destroys the omens of the false prophets

poetryblock.poem: and makes fools of diviners;
who confounds the wise
and makes their knowledge foolishness;

poem.verse: 26who confirms the message of his servant

poetryblock.poem: and fulfils the counsel of his messengers;
who says to Jerusalem, ‘She will be inhabited,’
and to the cities of Judah, ‘They will be rebuilt,’
and I will restore her ruins;

poem.verse: 27who says to the depths of the sea, ‘Be dry,’

poetryblock.poem: and I will dry up your rivers;

poem.verse: 28who says to Cyrus, ‘My shepherd,

poetryblock.poem: he will fulfil all my pleasure’
and says to Jerusalem, ‘She will be rebuilt,’
and of the temple, ‘Its foundation will be laid.’

poem.verse: 1The Lord says this to Cyrus, his anointed,

poetryblock.poem: whose right hand I have grasped
to subdue nations before him
and disarm kings,
to open doors before him,
and even city gates will not be shut:

poem.verse: 2‘I will go before you

poetryblock.poem: and level the uneven places;
I will shatter the bronze doors
and cut the iron bars in two.

poem.verse: 3I will give you the treasures of darkness

poetryblock.poem: and riches from secret places,
so that you may know that I am the Lord.
I am the God of Israel, who calls you by your name.

poem.verse: 4I call you by your name,

poetryblock.poem: for the sake of my servant Jacob
and Israel my chosen one.
I give a name to you,
though you do not know me.

poem.verse: 5I am the Lord, and there is no other;

poetryblock.poem: there is no God but me.
I will strengthen you,
though you do not know me,

poem.verse: 6so that all may know from the rising of the sun to its setting

poetryblock.poem: that there is no one but me.
I am the Lord, and there is no other.

poem.verse: 7I form light and create darkness,

poetryblock.poem: I make success and create disaster;
I am the Lord, who does all these things.

poem.verse: 8‘Heavens, sprinkle from above,

poetryblock.poem: and let the skies shower righteousness.
Let the earth open up
so that salvation will sprout
and righteousness will spring up with it.
I, the Lord, have created it.

poem.verse: 9‘Woe to the one who argues with his Maker –

poetryblock.poem: one clay pot among many.
Does clay say to the one forming it,
“What are you making? ”
Or does your work say,
“He has no hands”?

poem.verse: 10Woe to the one who says to his father,

poetryblock.poem: “What are you fathering? ”
or to his mother,
“What are you giving birth to? ” ’

poem.verse: 11This is what the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: the Holy One of Israel and its Maker, says:
‘Ask me what is to happen to my sons,
and instruct me about the work of my hands.

poem.verse: 12I made the earth,

poetryblock.poem: and created humans on it.
It was my hands that stretched out the heavens,
and I commanded everything in them.

poem.verse: 13I have stirred him up in righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: and will level all roads for him.
He will rebuild my city,
and set my exiles free,
not for a price or a bribe,’
says the Lord of Armies.

p.verse: 14This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: ‘The products of Egypt and the merchandise of Cush
and the Sabeans, men of stature,
will come over to you
and will be yours;
they will follow you,
they will come over in chains
and bow down to you.
They will confess to you,
“God is indeed with you, and there is no other;
there is no other God.” ’

poem.verse: 15Yes, you are a God who hides,

poetryblock.poem: God of Israel, Saviour.

poem.verse: 16All of them are put to shame, even humiliated;

poetryblock.poem: the makers of idols go in humiliation together.

poem.verse: 17Israel will be saved by the Lord

poetryblock.poem: with an everlasting salvation;
you will not be put to shame or humiliated
for all eternity.

poem.verse: 18For this is what the Lord says –

poetryblock.poem: the Creator of the heavens,
the God who formed the earth and made it,
the one who established it
(he did not create it to be a wasteland,
but formed it to be inhabited) –
he says, ‘I am the Lord,
and there is no other.

poem.verse: 19I have not spoken in secret,

poetryblock.poem: somewhere in a land of darkness.
I did not say to the descendants of Jacob:
Seek me in a wasteland.
I am the Lord, who speaks righteously,
who declares what is right.

poem.verse: 20‘Come, gather together,

poetryblock.poem: and approach, you fugitives of the nations.
Those who carry their wooden idols
and pray to a god who cannot save
have no knowledge.

poem.verse: 21Speak up and present your case –

poetryblock.poem: yes, let them consult each other.
Who predicted this long ago?
Who announced it from ancient times?
Was it not I, the Lord?
There is no other God but me,
a righteous God and Saviour;
there is no one except me.

poem.verse: 22Turn to me and be saved,

poetryblock.poem: all the ends of the earth.
For I am God,
and there is no other.

poem.verse: 23By myself I have sworn;

poetryblock.poem: truth has gone from my mouth,
a word that will not be revoked:
Every knee will bow to me,
every tongue will swear allegiance.

poem.verse: 24It will be said about me, “Righteousness and strength

poetryblock.poem: are found only in the Lord.” ’
All who are enraged against him
will come to him and be put to shame.

poem.verse: 25All the descendants of Israel

poetryblock.poem: will be justified and boast in the Lord.

chapter.head1: There Is No One Like God

poem.verse: 1Bel crouches; Nebo cowers.

poetryblock.poem: Idols depicting them are consigned to beasts and cattle.
The images you carry are loaded,
as a burden for the weary animal.

poem.verse: 2The gods cower; they crouch together;

poetryblock.poem: they are not able to rescue the burden,
but they themselves go into captivity.

poem.verse: 3‘Listen to me, house of Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: all the remnant of the house of Israel,
who have been sustained from the womb,
carried along since birth.

poem.verse: 4I will be the same until your old age,

poetryblock.poem: and I will bear you up when you turn grey.
I have made you, and I will carry you;
I will bear and rescue you.

poem.verse: 5‘To whom will you compare me or make me equal?

poetryblock.poem: Whom will you measure me with,
so that we should be like each other?

poem.verse: 6Those who pour out their bags of gold

poetryblock.poem: and weigh out silver on scales –
they hire a goldsmith and he makes it into a god.
Then they kneel and bow down to it.

poem.verse: 7They lift it to their shoulder and bear it along;

poetryblock.poem: they set it in its place, and there it stands;
it does not budge from its place.
They cry out to it but it doesn’t answer;
it saves no one from his trouble.

poem.verse: 8‘Remember this and be brave;

poetryblock.poem: take it to heart, you transgressors!

poem.verse: 9Remember what happened long ago,

poetryblock.poem: for I am God, and there is no other;
I am God, and no one is like me.

poem.verse: 10I declare the end from the beginning,

poetryblock.poem: and from long ago what is not yet done,
saying: my plan will take place,
and I will do all my will.

poem.verse: 11I call a bird of prey from the east,

poetryblock.poem: a man for my purpose from a far country.
Yes, I have spoken; so I will also bring it about.
I have planned it; I will also do it.

poem.verse: 12Listen to me, you hard-hearted,

poetryblock.poem: far removed from justice:

poem.verse: 13I am bringing my justice near;

poetryblock.poem: it is not far away,
and my salvation will not delay.
I will put salvation in Zion,
my splendour in Israel.

poem.verse: 1‘Go down and sit in the dust,

poetryblock.poem: Virgin Daughter Babylon.
Sit on the ground without a throne,
Daughter Chaldea!
For you will no longer be called pampered and spoilt.

poem.verse: 2Take millstones and grind flour;

poetryblock.poem: remove your veil,
strip off your skirt, bare your thigh,
wade through the streams.

poem.verse: 3Your nakedness will be uncovered,

poetryblock.poem: and your disgrace will be exposed.
I will take vengeance;
I will spare no one.’

poem.verse: 4The Holy One of Israel is our Redeemer;

poetryblock.poem: The Lord of Armies is his name.

poem.verse: 5‘Daughter Chaldea,

poetryblock.poem: sit in silence and go into darkness.
For you will no longer be called mistress of kingdoms.

poem.verse: 6I was angry with my people;

poetryblock.poem: I profaned my possession,
and I handed them over to you.
You showed them no mercy;
you made your yoke very heavy on the elderly.

poem.verse: 7You said, “I will be the queen for ever.”

poetryblock.poem: You did not take these things to heart
or think about their outcome.

poem.verse: 8‘So now hear this, lover of luxury,

poetryblock.poem: who sits securely,
who says to herself,
“I am, and there is no one else.
I will never be a widow
or know the loss of children.”

poem.verse: 9These two things will happen to you

poetryblock.poem: suddenly, in one day:
loss of children and widowhood.
They will happen to you in their entirety,
in spite of your many sorceries
and the potency of your spells.

poem.verse: 10You were secure in your wickedness;

poetryblock.poem: you said, “No one sees me.”
Your wisdom and knowledge
led you astray.
You said to yourself,
“I am, and there is no one else.”

poem.verse: 11But disaster will happen to you;

poetryblock.poem: you will not know how to avert it.
And it will fall on you,
but you will be unable to ward it off.
Devastation will happen to you suddenly
and unexpectedly.

poem.verse: 12So take your stand with your spells

poetryblock.poem: and your many sorceries,
which you have wearied yourself with from your youth.
Perhaps you will be able to succeed;
perhaps you will inspire terror!

poem.verse: 13You are worn out with your many consultations.

poetryblock.poem: So let the astrologers stand and save you –
those who observe the stars,
those who predict monthly
what will happen to you.

poem.verse: 14Look, they are like stubble;

poetryblock.poem: fire burns them.
They cannot rescue themselves
from the power of the flame.
This is not a coal for warming themselves,
or a fire to sit beside!

poem.verse: 15This is what they are to you –

poetryblock.poem: those who have wearied you
and have traded with you from your youth –
each wanders on his own way;
no one can save you.

poem.verse: 1‘Listen to this, house of Jacob –

poetryblock.poem: those who are called by the name Israel
and have descended from Judah,
who swear by the name of the Lord
and declare the God of Israel,
but not in truth or righteousness.

poem.verse: 2For they are named after the holy city,

poetryblock.poem: and lean on the God of Israel;
his name is the Lord of Armies.

poem.verse: 3I declared the past events long ago;

poetryblock.poem: they came out of my mouth; I proclaimed them.
Suddenly I acted, and they occurred.

poem.verse: 4Because I know that you are stubborn,

poetryblock.poem: and your neck is iron
and your forehead bronze,

poem.verse: 5therefore I declared to you long ago.

poetryblock.poem: I announced it to you before it occurred,
so you could not claim, “My idol caused them;
my carved image and cast idol control them.”

poem.verse: 6You have heard it. Observe it all.

poetryblock.poem: Will you not acknowledge it?
From now on I will announce new things to you,
hidden things that you have not known.

poem.verse: 7They have been created now, and not long ago;

poetryblock.poem: you have not heard of them before today,
so you could not claim, “I already knew them! ”

poem.verse: 8You have never heard; you have never known;

poetryblock.poem: for a long time your ears have not been open.
For I knew that you were very treacherous,
and were known as a rebel from birth.

poem.verse: 9I will delay my anger for the sake of my name,

poetryblock.poem: and I will restrain myself for your benefit and for my praise,
so that you will not be destroyed.

poem.verse: 10Look, I have refined you, but not as silver;

poetryblock.poem: I have tested you in the furnace of affliction.

poem.verse: 11I will act for my own sake, indeed, my own,

poetryblock.poem: for how can I be defiled?
I will not give my glory to another.

poem.verse: 12‘Listen to me, Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: and Israel, the one called by me:
I am he; I am the first,
I am also the last.

poem.verse: 13My own hand founded the earth,

poetryblock.poem: and my right hand spread out the heavens;
when I summoned them,
they stood up together.

poem.verse: 14All of you, assemble and listen!

poetryblock.poem: Who among the idols has declared these things?
The Lord loves him;
he will accomplish his will against Babylon,
and his arm will be against the Chaldeans.

poem.verse: 15I ​– ​I have spoken;

poetryblock.poem: yes, I have called him;
I have brought him,
and he will succeed in his mission.

poem.verse: 16Approach me and listen to this.

poetryblock.poem: From the beginning I have not spoken in secret;
from the time anything existed, I was there.’
And now the Lord God
has sent me and his Spirit.

p.verse: 17This is what the Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel says:

poetryblock.poem: I am the Lord your God,
who teaches you for your benefit,
who leads you in the way you should go.

poem.verse: 18If only you had paid attention to my commands.

poetryblock.poem: Then your peace would have been like a river,
