and your righteousness like the waves of the sea.

poem.verse: 19Your descendants would have been as countless as the sand,

poetryblock.poem: and the offspring of your body like its grains;
their name would not be cut off
or eliminated from my presence.

poem.verse: 20Leave Babylon,

poetryblock.poem: flee from the Chaldeans!
Declare with a shout of joy,
proclaim this,
let it go out to the end of the earth;
announce,
‘The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob! ’

poem.verse: 21They did not thirst

poetryblock.poem: when he led them through the deserts;
he made water flow from the rock for them;
he split the rock, and water gushed out.

poem.verse: 22‘There is no peace for the wicked,’ says the Lord.
1Coasts and islands, listen to me;

poetryblock.poem: distant peoples, pay attention.
The Lord called me before I was born.
He named me while I was in my mother’s womb.

poem.verse: 2He made my words like a sharp sword;

poetryblock.poem: he hid me in the shadow of his hand.
He made me like a sharpened arrow;
he hid me in his quiver.

poem.verse: 3He said to me, ‘You are my servant,

poetryblock.poem: Israel, in whom I will be glorified.’

poem.verse: 4But I myself said: I have laboured in vain,

poetryblock.poem: I have spent my strength for nothing and futility;
yet my vindication is with the Lord,
and my reward is with my God.

poem.verse: 5And now, says the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: who formed me from the womb to be his servant,
to bring Jacob back to him
so that Israel might be gathered to him;
for I am honoured in the sight of the Lord,
and my God is my strength –

poem.verse: 6he says,

poetryblock.poem: ‘It is not enough for you to be my servant
raising up the tribes of Jacob
and restoring the protected ones of Israel.
I will also make you a light for the nations,
to be my salvation to the ends of the earth.’

poem.verse: 7This is what the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: the Redeemer of Israel, his Holy One, says
to one who is despised,
to one abhorred by people,
to a servant of rulers:
‘Kings will see, princes will stand up,
and they will all bow down
because of the Lord, who is faithful,
the Holy One of Israel ​– ​and he has chosen you.’

p.verse: 8This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will answer you in a time of favour,
and I will help you in the day of salvation.
I will keep you, and I will appoint you
to be a covenant for the people,
to restore the land,
to make them possess the desolate inheritances,

poem.verse: 9saying to the prisoners, ‘Come out,’

poetryblock.poem: and to those who are in darkness, ‘Show yourselves.’
They will feed along the pathways,
and their pastures will be on all the barren heights.

poem.verse: 10They will not hunger or thirst,

poetryblock.poem: the scorching heat or sun will not strike them;
for their compassionate one will guide them,
and lead them to springs.

poem.verse: 11I will make all my mountains into a pathway,

poetryblock.poem: and my roads will be raised up.

poem.verse: 12See, these will come from far away,

poetryblock.poem: from the north and from the west,
and from the land of Sinim.

poem.verse: 13Shout for joy, you heavens!

poetryblock.poem: Earth, rejoice!
Mountains, break into joyful shouts!
For the Lord has comforted his people,
and will have compassion on his afflicted ones.

poem.verse: 14Zion says, ‘The Lord has abandoned me;

poetryblock.poem: the Lord has forgotten me! ’

poem.verse: 15‘Can a woman forget her nursing child,

poetryblock.poem: or lack compassion for the child of her womb?
Even if these forget,
yet I will not forget you.

poem.verse: 16Look, I have inscribed you on the palms of my hands;

poetryblock.poem: your walls are continually before me.

poem.verse: 17Your builders hurry;

poetryblock.poem: those who destroy and devastate you will leave you.

poem.verse: 18Look up, and look round.

poetryblock.poem: They all gather together; they come to you.
As I live’ –
this is the Lord’s declaration –
‘you will wear all your children as jewellery,
and put them on as a bride does.

poem.verse: 19For your waste and desolate places

poetryblock.poem: and your land marked by ruins
will now be indeed too small for the inhabitants,
and those who swallowed you up will be far away.

poem.verse: 20Yet as you listen, the children

poetryblock.poem: that you have been deprived of will say,
“This place is too small for me;
make room for me so that I may settle.”

poem.verse: 21Then you will say within yourself,

poetryblock.poem: “Who fathered these for me?
I was deprived of my children and unable to conceive,
exiled and wandering –
but who brought them up?
See, I was left by myself –
but these, where did they come from? ” ’

p.verse: 22This is what the Lord God says:

poetryblock.poem: Look, I will lift up my hand to the nations,
and raise my banner to the peoples.
They will bring your sons in their arms,
and your daughters will be carried on their shoulders.

poem.verse: 23Kings will be your guardians

poetryblock.poem: and their queens your nursing mothers.
They will bow down to you
with their faces to the ground
and lick the dust at your feet.
Then you will know that I am the Lord;
those who put their hope in me
will not be put to shame.

poem.verse: 24Can the prey be taken from a mighty man,

poetryblock.poem: or the captives of a tyrant be delivered?

poem.verse: 25For this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Even the captives of a mighty man will be taken,
and the prey of a tyrant will be delivered;
I will contend with the one who contends with you,
and I will save your children.

poem.verse: 26I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh,

poetryblock.poem: and they will be drunk with their own blood
as with sweet wine.
Then all humanity will know
that I, the Lord, am your Saviour,
and your Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.’

p.verse: 1This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Where is your mother’s divorce certificate
that I used to send her away?
Or to which of my creditors did I sell you?
Look, you were sold for your iniquities,
and your mother was sent away
because of your transgressions.

poem.verse: 2Why was no one there when I came?

poetryblock.poem: Why was there no one to answer when I called?
Is my arm too weak to redeem?
Or do I have no power to rescue?
Look, I dry up the sea by my rebuke;
I turn the rivers into a wilderness;
their fish rot because of lack of water
and die of thirst.

poem.verse: 3I dress the heavens in black

poetryblock.poem: and make sackcloth their covering.

poem.verse: 4The Lord God has given me

poetryblock.poem: the tongue of those who are instructed
to know how to sustain the weary with a word.
He awakens me each morning;
he awakens my ear to listen like those being instructed.

poem.verse: 5The Lord God has opened my ear,

poetryblock.poem: and I was not rebellious;
I did not turn back.

poem.verse: 6I gave my back to those who beat me,

poetryblock.poem: and my cheeks to those who tore out my beard.
I did not hide my face from scorn and spitting.

poem.verse: 7The Lord God will help me;

poetryblock.poem: therefore I have not been humiliated;
therefore I have set my face like flint,
and I know I will not be put to shame.

poem.verse: 8The one who vindicates me is near;

poetryblock.poem: who will contend with me?
Let us confront each other.
Who has a case against me?
Let him come near me!

poem.verse: 9In truth, the Lord God will help me;

poetryblock.poem: who will condemn me?
Indeed, all of them will wear out like a garment;
a moth will devour them.

poem.verse: 10Who among you fears the Lord

poetryblock.poem: and listens to his servant?
Who among you walks in darkness,
and has no light?
Let him trust in the name of the Lord;
let him lean on his God.

poem.verse: 11Look, all you who kindle a fire,

poetryblock.poem: who encircle yourselves with torches;
walk in the light of your fire
and of the torches you have lit!
This is what you’ll get from my hand:
you will lie down in a place of torment.

poem.verse: 1Listen to me, you who pursue righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: you who seek the Lord:
Look to the rock from which you were cut,
and to the quarry from which you were dug.

poem.verse: 2Look to Abraham your father,

poetryblock.poem: and to Sarah who gave birth to you.
When I called him, he was only one;
I blessed him and made him many.

poem.verse: 3For the Lord will comfort Zion;

poetryblock.poem: he will comfort all her waste places,
and he will make her wilderness like Eden,
and her desert like the garden of the Lord.
Joy and gladness will be found in her,
thanksgiving and melodious song.

poem.verse: 4Pay attention to me, my people,

poetryblock.poem: and listen to me, my nation;
for instruction will come from me,
and my justice for a light to the nations.
I will bring it about quickly.

poem.verse: 5My righteousness is near,

poetryblock.poem: my salvation appears,
and my arms will bring justice to the nations.
The coasts and islands will put their hope in me,
and they will look to my strength.

poem.verse: 6Look up to the heavens,

poetryblock.poem: and look at the earth beneath;
for the heavens will vanish like smoke,
the earth will wear out like a garment,
and its inhabitants will die like gnats.
But my salvation will last for ever,
and my righteousness will never be shattered.

poem.verse: 7Listen to me, you who know righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: the people in whose heart is my instruction:
do not fear disgrace by men,
and do not be shattered by their taunts.

poem.verse: 8For moths will devour them like a garment,

poetryblock.poem: and worms will eat them like wool.
But my righteousness will last for ever,
and my salvation for all generations.

poem.verse: 9Wake up, wake up!

poetryblock.poem: Arm of the Lord, clothe yourself with strength.
Wake up as in days past,
as in generations long ago.
Wasn’t it you who hacked Rahab to pieces,
who pierced the sea monster?

poem.verse: 10Wasn’t it you who dried up the sea,

poetryblock.poem: the waters of the great deep,
who made the sea-bed into a road
for the redeemed to pass over?

poem.verse: 11And the ransomed of the Lord will return

poetryblock.poem: and come to Zion with singing,
crowned with unending joy.
Joy and gladness will overtake them,
and sorrow and sighing will flee.

poem.verse: 12I ​– ​I am the one who comforts you.

poetryblock.poem: Who are you that you should fear humans who die,
or a son of man who is given up like grass?

poem.verse: 13But you have forgotten the Lord, your Maker,

poetryblock.poem: who stretched out the heavens
and laid the foundations of the earth.
You are in constant dread all day long
because of the fury of the oppressor,
who has set himself to destroy.
But where is the fury of the oppressor?

poem.verse: 14The prisoner is soon to be set free;

poetryblock.poem: he will not die and go to the Pit,
and his food will not be lacking.

poem.verse: 15For I am the Lord your God

poetryblock.poem: who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar –
his name is the Lord of Armies.

poem.verse: 16I have put my words in your mouth,

poetryblock.poem: and covered you in the shadow of my hand,
in order to plant the heavens,
to found the earth,
and to say to Zion, ‘You are my people.’

poem.verse: 17Wake yourself, wake yourself up!

poetryblock.poem: Stand up, Jerusalem,
you who have drunk the cup of his fury
from the Lord’s hand;
you who have drunk the goblet to the dregs –
the cup that causes people to stagger.

poem.verse: 18There is no one to guide her

poetryblock.poem: among all the children she has brought up;
there is no one to take hold of her hand
among all the offspring she has brought up.

poem.verse: 19These two things have happened to you:

poetryblock.poem: devastation and destruction,
famine and sword.
Who will grieve for you?
How can I comfort you?

poem.verse: 20Your children have fainted;

poetryblock.poem: they lie at the head of every street
like an antelope in a net.
They are full of the Lord’s fury,
the rebuke of your God.

poem.verse: 21So listen to this, suffering

poetryblock.poem: and drunken one ​– ​but not with wine.

poem.verse: 22This is what your Lord says –

poetryblock.poem: the Lord, even your God,
who defends his people –
‘Look, I have removed from your hand
the cup that causes staggering;
that goblet, the cup of my fury.
You will never drink it again.

poem.verse: 23I will put it into the hands of your tormentors,

poetryblock.poem: who said to you,
“Lie down, so that we can walk over you.”
You made your back like the ground,
and like a street for those who walk on it.

poem.verse: 1‘Wake up, wake up;

poetryblock.poem: put on your strength, Zion!
Put on your beautiful garments,
Jerusalem, the holy city!
For the uncircumcised and the unclean
will no longer enter you.

poem.verse: 2Stand up, shake the dust off yourself!

poetryblock.poem: Take your seat, Jerusalem.
Remove the bonds from your neck,
captive Daughter Zion.’

poem.verse: 3For this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: ‘You were sold for nothing,
and you will be redeemed without silver.’

poem.verse: 4For this is what the Lord God says:

poetryblock.poem: ‘At first my people went down to Egypt to reside there,
then Assyria oppressed them without cause.

poem.verse: 5So now what have I here’ –

poetryblock.poem: this is the Lord’s declaration –
‘that my people are taken away for nothing?
Its rulers wail’ –
this is the Lord’s declaration –
‘and my name is continually blasphemed all day long.

poem.verse: 6Therefore my people will know my name;

poetryblock.poem: therefore they will know on that day
that I am he who says,
“Here I am.” ’

poem.verse: 7How beautiful on the mountains

poetryblock.poem: are the feet of the herald,
who proclaims peace,
who brings news of good things,
who proclaims salvation,
who says to Zion, ‘Your God reigns! ’

poem.verse: 8The voices of your watchmen –

poetryblock.poem: they lift up their voices,
shouting for joy together;
for every eye will see
when the Lord returns to Zion.

poem.verse: 9Be joyful, rejoice together,

poetryblock.poem: you ruins of Jerusalem!
For the Lord has comforted his people;
he has redeemed Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 10The Lord has displayed his holy arm

poetryblock.poem: in the sight of all the nations;
all the ends of the earth will see
the salvation of our God.

poem.verse: 11Leave, leave, go out from there!

poetryblock.poem: Do not touch anything unclean;
go out from her, purify yourselves,
you who carry the vessels of the Lord.

poem.verse: 12For you will not leave in a hurry,

poetryblock.poem: and you will not have to take flight;
because the Lord is going before you,
and the God of Israel is your rear guard.

poem.verse: 13See, my servant will be successful;

poetryblock.poem: he will be raised and lifted up and greatly exalted.

poem.verse: 14Just as many were appalled at you –

poetryblock.poem: his appearance was so disfigured
that he did not look like a man,
and his form did not resemble a human being –

poem.verse: 15so he will sprinkle many nations.

poetryblock.poem: Kings will shut their mouths because of him,
for they will see what had not been told them,
and they will understand what they had not heard.

poem.verse: 1Who has believed what we have heard?

poetryblock.poem: And to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?

poem.verse: 2He grew up before him like a young plant

poetryblock.poem: and like a root out of dry ground.
He didn’t have an impressive form
or majesty that we should look at him,
no appearance that we should desire him.

poem.verse: 3He was despised and rejected by men,

poetryblock.poem: a man of suffering who knew what sickness was.
He was like someone people turned away from;
he was despised, and we didn’t value him.

poem.verse: 4Yet he himself bore our sicknesses,

poetryblock.poem: and he carried our pains;
but we in turn regarded him stricken,
struck down by God, and afflicted.

poem.verse: 5But he was pierced because of our rebellion,

poetryblock.poem: crushed because of our iniquities;
punishment for our peace was on him,
and we are healed by his wounds.

poem.verse: 6We all went astray like sheep;

poetryblock.poem: we all have turned to our own way;
and the Lord has punished him
for the iniquity of us all.

poem.verse: 7He was oppressed and afflicted,

poetryblock.poem: yet he did not open his mouth.
Like a lamb led to the slaughter
and like a sheep silent before her shearers,
he did not open his mouth.

poem.verse: 8He was taken away because of oppression and judgement,

poetryblock.poem: and who considered his fate?
For he was cut off from the land of the living;
he was struck because of my people’s rebellion.

poem.verse: 9He was assigned a grave with the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: but he was with a rich man at his death,
because he had done no violence
and had not spoken deceitfully.

poem.verse: 10Yet the Lord was pleased to crush him severely.

poetryblock.poem: When you make him a guilt offering,
he will see his seed, he will prolong his days,
and by his hand the Lord’s pleasure will be accomplished.

poem.verse: 11After his anguish,

poetryblock.poem: he will see light and be satisfied.
By his knowledge,
my righteous servant will justify many,
and he will carry their iniquities.

poem.verse: 12Therefore I will give him the many as a portion,

poetryblock.poem: and he will receive the mighty as spoil,
because he willingly submitted to death,
and was counted among the rebels;
yet he bore the sin of many
and interceded for the rebels.

poem.verse: 1‘Rejoice, childless one, who did not give birth;

poetryblock.poem: burst into song and shout,
you who have not been in labour!
For the children of the desolate one will be more
than the children of the married woman,’
says the Lord.

poem.verse: 2‘Enlarge the site of your tent,

poetryblock.poem: and let your tent curtains be stretched out;
do not hold back;
lengthen your ropes,
and drive your pegs deep.

poem.verse: 3For you will spread out to the right and to the left,

poetryblock.poem: and your descendants will dispossess nations
and inhabit the desolate cities.

poem.verse: 4‘Do not be afraid, for you will not be put to shame;

poetryblock.poem: don’t be humiliated, for you will not be disgraced.
For you will forget the shame of your youth,
and you will no longer remember
the disgrace of your widowhood.

poem.verse: 5Indeed, your husband is your Maker –

poetryblock.poem: his name is the Lord of Armies –
and the Holy One of Israel is your Redeemer;
he is called the God of the whole earth.

poem.verse: 6For the Lord has called you,

poetryblock.poem: like a wife deserted and wounded in spirit,
a wife of one’s youth when she is rejected,’
says your God.

poem.verse: 7‘I deserted you for a brief moment,

poetryblock.poem: but I will take you back with abundant compassion.

poem.verse: 8In a surge of anger

poetryblock.poem: I hid my face from you for a moment,
but I will have compassion on you
with everlasting love,’
says the Lord your Redeemer.

poem.verse: 9‘For this is like the days of Noah to me:

poetryblock.poem: when I swore that the water of Noah
would never flood the earth again,
so I have sworn that I will not be angry with you
or rebuke you.

poem.verse: 10Though the mountains move

poetryblock.poem: and the hills shake,
my love will not be removed from you
and my covenant of peace will not be shaken,’
says your compassionate Lord.

poem.verse: 11‘Poor Jerusalem, storm-tossed, and not comforted,

poetryblock.poem: I will set your stones in black mortar,
and lay your foundations in lapis lazuli.

poem.verse: 12I will make your fortifications out of rubies,

poetryblock.poem: your gates out of sparkling stones,
and all your walls out of precious stones.

poem.verse: 13Then all your children will be taught by the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: their prosperity will be great,

poem.verse: 14and you will be established

poetryblock.poem: on a foundation of righteousness.
You will be far from oppression,
you will certainly not be afraid;
you will be far from terror,
it will certainly not come near you.

poem.verse: 15If anyone attacks you,

poetryblock.poem: it is not from me;
whoever attacks you
will fall before you.

poem.verse: 16Look, I have created the craftsman

poetryblock.poem: who blows on the charcoal fire
and produces a weapon suitable for its task;
and I have created the destroyer to cause havoc.

poem.verse: 17No weapon formed against you will succeed,

poetryblock.poem: and you will refute any accusation
raised against you in court.
This is the heritage of the Lord’s servants,
and their vindication is from me.’

poem.verse: 1‘Come, everyone who is thirsty,

poetryblock.poem: come to the water;
and you without silver,
come, buy, and eat!
Come, buy wine and milk
without silver and without cost!

poem.verse: 2Why do you spend silver on what is not food,

poetryblock.poem: and your wages on what does not satisfy?
Listen carefully to me, and eat what is good,
and you will enjoy the choicest of foods.

poem.verse: 3Pay attention and come to me;

poetryblock.poem: listen, so that you will live.
I will make a permanent covenant with you
on the basis of the faithful kindnesses of David.

poem.verse: 4Since I have made him a witness to the peoples,

poetryblock.poem: a leader and commander for the peoples,

poem.verse: 5so you will summon a nation you do not know,

poetryblock.poem: and nations who do not know you will run to you.
For the Lord your God,
even the Holy One of Israel,
has glorified you.’

poem.verse: 6Seek the Lord while he may be found;

poetryblock.poem: call to him while he is near.

poem.verse: 7Let the wicked one abandon his way

poetryblock.poem: and the sinful one his thoughts;
let him return to the Lord,
so that he may have compassion on him,
and to our God, for he will freely forgive.

poem.verse: 8‘For my thoughts are not your thoughts,

poetryblock.poem: and your ways are not my ways.’
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 9‘For as heaven is higher than earth,

poetryblock.poem: so my ways are higher than your ways,
and my thoughts than your thoughts.

poem.verse: 10For just as rain and snow fall from heaven

poetryblock.poem: and do not return there
without saturating the earth
and making it germinate and sprout,
and providing seed to sow
and food to eat,

poem.verse: 11so my word that comes from my mouth

poetryblock.poem: will not return to me empty,
but it will accomplish what I please
and will prosper in what I send it to do.’

poem.verse: 12You will indeed go out with joy

poetryblock.poem: and be peacefully guided;
the mountains and the hills will break into singing before you,
and all the trees of the field will clap their hands.

poem.verse: 13Instead of the thorn bush, a cypress will come up,

poetryblock.poem: and instead of the briar, a myrtle will come up;
this will stand as a monument for the Lord,
an everlasting sign that will not be destroyed.

chapter.head1: A House of Prayer for All

p.verse: 1This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Preserve justice and do what is right,
for my salvation is coming soon,
and my righteousness will be revealed.

poem.verse: 2Happy is the person who does this,

poetryblock.poem: the son of man who holds it fast,
who keeps the Sabbath without desecrating it,
and keeps his hand from doing any evil.

poem.verse: 3No foreigner who has joined himself to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: should say,
‘The Lord will exclude me from his people,’
and the eunuch should not say,
‘Look, I am a dried-up tree.’

poem.verse: 4For the Lord says this:

poetryblock.poem: ‘For the eunuchs who keep my Sabbaths,
and choose what pleases me,
and hold firmly to my covenant,

poem.verse: 5I will give them, in my house and within my walls,

poetryblock.poem: a memorial and a name
better than sons and daughters.
I will give each of them an everlasting name
that will never be cut off.

poem.verse: 6As for the foreigners who join themselves to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: to minister to him, to love the name of the Lord,
and to become his servants –
all who keep the Sabbath without desecrating it
and who hold firmly to my covenant –

poem.verse: 7I will bring them to my holy mountain

poetryblock.poem: and let them rejoice in my house of prayer.
Their burnt offerings and sacrifices
will be acceptable on my altar,
for my house will be called a house of prayer
for all nations.’

poem.verse: 8This is the declaration of the Lord God,

poetryblock.poem: who gathers the dispersed of Israel:
‘I will gather to them still others
besides those already gathered.’

poem.verse: 9All you animals of the field and forest,

poetryblock.poem: come and eat!

poem.verse: 10Israel’s watchmen are blind, all of them,

poetryblock.poem: they know nothing;
all of them are mute dogs,
they cannot bark;
they dream, lie down,
and love to sleep.

poem.verse: 11These dogs have fierce appetites;

poetryblock.poem: they never have enough.
And they are shepherds
who have no discernment;
all of them turn to their own way,
every last one for his own profit.

poem.verse: 12‘Come, let me get some wine,

poetryblock.poem: let’s guzzle some beer;
and tomorrow will be like today,
only far better! ’

poem.verse: 1The righteous person perishes,

poetryblock.poem: and no one takes it to heart;
the faithful are taken away,
with no one realising
that the righteous person is taken away
because of evil.

poem.verse: 2He will enter into peace –

poetryblock.poem: they will rest on their beds –
everyone who lives uprightly.

poem.verse: 3But come here,

poetryblock.poem: you witch’s sons,
offspring of an adulterer and a prostitute!

poem.verse: 4Who are you mocking?

poetryblock.poem: Who are you opening your mouth
and sticking out your tongue at?
Isn’t it you, you rebellious children,
you offspring of liars,

poem.verse: 5who burn with lust among the oaks,

poetryblock.poem: under every green tree,
who slaughter children in the wadis
below the clefts of the rocks?

poem.verse: 6Your portion is among the smooth stones of the wadi;

poetryblock.poem: indeed, they are your lot.
You have even poured out a drink offering to them;
you have offered a grain offering;
should I be satisfied with these?

poem.verse: 7You have placed your bed

poetryblock.poem: on a high and lofty mountain;
you also went up there to offer sacrifice.

poem.verse: 8You have set up your memorial

poetryblock.poem: behind the door and doorpost.
For away from me, you stripped,
went up, and made your bed wide,
and you have made a bargain for yourself with them.
You have loved their bed;
you have gazed on their genitals.

poem.verse: 9You went to the king with oil

poetryblock.poem: and multiplied your perfumes;
you sent your envoys far away
and sent them down even to Sheol.

poem.verse: 10You became weary on your many journeys,

poetryblock.poem: but you did not say, ‘It’s hopeless! ’
You found a renewal of your strength;
therefore you did not grow weak.

poem.verse: 11Who was it you dreaded and feared,

poetryblock.poem: so that you lied and didn’t remember me
or take it to heart?
I have kept silent for a long time, haven’t I?
So you do not fear me.

poem.verse: 12I will announce your righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: and your works ​– ​they will not profit you.

poem.verse: 13When you cry out,

poetryblock.poem: let your collection of idols rescue you!
The wind will carry all of them off,
a breath will take them away.
But whoever takes refuge in me
will inherit the land
and possess my holy mountain.

poem.verse: 14He said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Build it up, build it up, prepare the way,
remove every obstacle from my people’s way.’

poem.verse: 15For the High and Exalted One,

poetryblock.poem: who lives for ever, whose name is holy, says this:
‘I live in a high and holy place,
and with the oppressed and lowly of spirit,
to revive the spirit of the lowly
and revive the heart of the oppressed.

poem.verse: 16For I will not accuse you for ever,

poetryblock.poem: and I will not always be angry;
for then the spirit would grow weak before me,
even the breath, which I have made.

poem.verse: 17Because of his sinful greed I was angry,

poetryblock.poem: so I struck him; I was angry and hid;
but he went on turning back to the desires of his heart.

poem.verse: 18I have seen his ways, but I will heal him;

poetryblock.poem: I will lead him and restore comfort
to him and his mourners,

poem.verse: 19creating words of praise.’

poetryblock.poem: The Lord says,
‘Peace, peace to the one who is far or near,
and I will heal him.

poem.verse: 20But the wicked are like the storm-tossed sea,

poetryblock.poem: for it cannot be still,
and its water churns up mire and muck.

poem.verse: 21There is no peace for the wicked,’

poetryblock.poem: says my God.

poem.verse: 1‘Cry out loudly, don’t hold back!

poetryblock.poem: Raise your voice like a ram’s horn.
Tell my people their transgression
and the house of Jacob their sins.

poem.verse: 2They seek me day after day

poetryblock.poem: and delight to know my ways,
like a nation that does what is right
and does not abandon the justice of their God.
They ask me for righteous judgements;
they delight in the nearness of God.’

poem.verse: 3‘Why have we fasted, but you have not seen?

poetryblock.poem: We have denied ourselves, but you haven’t noticed! ’
‘Look, you do as you please on the day of your fast,
and oppress all your workers.

poem.verse: 4You fast with contention and strife

poetryblock.poem: to strike viciously with your fist.
You cannot fast as you do today,
hoping to make your voice heard on high.

poem.verse: 5Will the fast I choose be like this:

poetryblock.poem: A day for a person to deny himself,
to bow his head like a reed,
and to spread out sackcloth and ashes?
Will you call this a fast
and a day acceptable to the Lord?

poem.verse: 6Isn’t this the fast I choose:

poetryblock.poem: To break the chains of wickedness,
to untie the ropes of the yoke,
to set the oppressed free,
and to tear off every yoke?

poem.verse: 7Is it not to share your bread with the hungry,

poetryblock.poem: to bring the poor and homeless into your house,
to clothe the naked when you see him,
and not to ignore your own flesh and blood?

poem.verse: 8Then your light will appear like the dawn,

poetryblock.poem: and your recovery will come quickly.
Your righteousness will go before you,
and the Lord’s glory will be your rear guard.

poem.verse: 9At that time, when you call, the Lord will answer;

poetryblock.poem: when you cry out, he will say, “Here I am.”
If you get rid of the yoke among you,
the finger-pointing and malicious speaking,

poem.verse: 10and if you offer yourself to the hungry,

poetryblock.poem: and satisfy the afflicted one,
then your light will shine in the darkness,
and your night will be like noonday.

poem.verse: 11The Lord will always lead you,

poetryblock.poem: satisfy you in a parched land,
and strengthen your bones.
You will be like a watered garden
and like a spring whose water never runs dry.

poem.verse: 12Some of you will rebuild the ancient ruins;

poetryblock.poem: you will restore the foundations laid long ago;
you will be called the repairer of broken walls,
the restorer of streets where people live.

poem.verse: 13‘If you avoid desecrating the Sabbath,

poetryblock.poem: from doing whatever you want on my holy day;
if you call the Sabbath a delight,
and the holy day of the Lord honourable;
if you honour it, not going your own ways,
seeking your own pleasure, or talking business;

poem.verse: 14then you will delight in the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and I will make you ride over the heights of the land,
and let you enjoy the heritage of your father Jacob.’
For the mouth of the Lord has spoken.

poem.verse: 1Indeed, the Lord’s arm is not too weak to save,

poetryblock.poem: and his ear is not too deaf to hear.

poem.verse: 2But your iniquities are separating you

poetryblock.poem: from your God,
and your sins have hidden his face from you
so that he does not listen.

poem.verse: 3For your hands are defiled with blood,

poetryblock.poem: and your fingers with iniquity;
your lips have spoken lies,
and your tongues mutter injustice.

poem.verse: 4No one makes claims justly;

poetryblock.poem: no one pleads honestly.
They trust in empty and worthless words;
they conceive trouble and give birth to iniquity.

poem.verse: 5They hatch viper’s eggs

poetryblock.poem: and weave spider’s webs.
Whoever eats their eggs will die;
crack one open, and a viper is hatched.

poem.verse: 6Their webs cannot become clothing,

poetryblock.poem: and they cannot cover themselves with their works.
Their works are sinful works,
and violent acts are in their hands.

poem.verse: 7Their feet run after evil,

poetryblock.poem: and they rush to shed innocent blood.
Their thoughts are sinful thoughts;
ruin and wretchedness are in their paths.

poem.verse: 8They have not known the path of peace,

poetryblock.poem: and there is no justice in their ways.
They have made their roads crooked;
no one who walks on them will know peace.

poem.verse: 9Therefore justice is far from us,

poetryblock.poem: and righteousness does not reach us.
We hope for light, but there is darkness;
for brightness, but we live in the night.

poem.verse: 10We grope along a wall like the blind;

poetryblock.poem: we grope like those without eyes.
We stumble at noon as though it were twilight;
we are like the dead among those who are healthy.

poem.verse: 11We all growl like bears

poetryblock.poem: and moan like doves.
We hope for justice, but there is none;
for salvation, but it is far from us.

poem.verse: 12For our transgressions have multiplied before you,

poetryblock.poem: and our sins testify against us.
For our transgressions are with us,
and we know our iniquities:

poem.verse: 13transgression and deception against the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: turning away from following our God,
speaking oppression and revolt,
conceiving and uttering lying words from the heart.

poem.verse: 14Justice is turned back,

poetryblock.poem: and righteousness stands far off.
For truth has stumbled in the public square,
and honesty cannot enter.

poem.verse: 15Truth is missing,

poetryblock.poem: and whoever turns from evil is plundered.
The Lord saw that there was no justice,
and he was offended.

poem.verse: 16He saw that there was no man –

poetryblock.poem: he was amazed that there was no one interceding;
so his own arm brought salvation,
and his own righteousness supported him.

poem.verse: 17He put on righteousness as body armour,

poetryblock.poem: and a helmet of salvation on his head;
he put on garments of vengeance for clothing,
and he wrapped himself in zeal as in a cloak.

poem.verse: 18So he will repay according to their deeds:

poetryblock.poem: fury to his enemies,
retribution to his foes,
and he will repay the coasts and islands.

poem.verse: 19They will fear the name of the Lord in the west

poetryblock.poem: and his glory in the east;
for he will come like a rushing stream
driven by the wind of the Lord.

poem.verse: 20‘The Redeemer will come to Zion,

poetryblock.poem: and to those in Jacob who turn from transgression.’
This is the Lord’s declaration.

p.verse: 21‘As for me, this is my covenant with them,’ says the Lord: ‘My Spirit who is on you, and my words that I have put in your mouth, will not depart from your mouth, or from the mouths of your children, or from the mouths of your children’s children, from now on and for ever,’ says the Lord.

poem.verse: 1Arise, shine, for your light has come,

poetryblock.poem: and the glory of the Lord shines over you.

poem.verse: 2For look, darkness will cover the earth,

poetryblock.poem: and total darkness the peoples;
but the Lord will shine over you,
and his glory will appear over you.

poem.verse: 3Nations will come to your light,

poetryblock.poem: and kings to your shining brightness.

poem.verse: 4Raise your eyes and look round:

poetryblock.poem: they all gather and come to you;
your sons will come from far away,
and your daughters on the hips of nursing mothers.

poem.verse: 5Then you will see and be radiant,

poetryblock.poem: and your heart will tremble and rejoice,
because the riches of the sea will become yours
and the wealth of the nations will come to you.

poem.verse: 6Caravans of camels will cover your land –

poetryblock.poem: young camels of Midian and Ephah –
all of them will come from Sheba.
They will carry gold and frankincense
and proclaim the praises of the Lord.

poem.verse: 7All the flocks of Kedar will be gathered to you;

poetryblock.poem: the rams of Nebaioth will serve you
and go up on my altar as an acceptable sacrifice.
I will glorify my beautiful house.

poem.verse: 8Who are these who fly like a cloud,

poetryblock.poem: like doves to their shelters?

poem.verse: 9Yes, the coasts and islands will wait for me

poetryblock.poem: with the ships of Tarshish in the lead,
to bring your children from far away,
their silver and gold with them,
for the honour of the Lord your God,
the Holy One of Israel,
who has glorified you.

poem.verse: 10Foreigners will rebuild your walls,

poetryblock.poem: and their kings will serve you.
Although I struck you in my wrath,
yet I will show mercy to you with my favour.

poem.verse: 11Your city gates will always be open;

poetryblock.poem: they will never be shut day or night
so that the wealth of the nations
may be brought into you,
with their kings being led in procession.

poem.verse: 12For the nation and the kingdom

poetryblock.poem: that will not serve you will perish;
those nations will be annihilated.

poem.verse: 13The glory of Lebanon will come to you –

poetryblock.poem: its pine, elm, and cypress together –
to beautify the place of my sanctuary,
and I will glorify my dwelling place.

poem.verse: 14The sons of your oppressors

poetryblock.poem: will come and bow down to you;
all who reviled you
will fall face down at your feet.
They will call you the City of the Lord,
Zion of the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 15Instead of your being deserted and hated,

poetryblock.poem: with no one passing through,
I will make you an object of eternal pride,
a joy from age to age.

poem.verse: 16You will nurse on the milk of nations,

poetryblock.poem: and nurse at the breast of kings;
you will know that I, the Lord, am your Saviour
and Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.

poem.verse: 17I will bring gold instead of bronze;

poetryblock.poem: I will bring silver instead of iron,
bronze instead of wood,
and iron instead of stones.
I will appoint peace as your government
and righteousness as your overseers.

poem.verse: 18Violence will never again be heard of in your land;

poetryblock.poem: devastation and destruction
will be gone from your borders.
You will call your walls Salvation
and your city gates Praise.

poem.verse: 19The sun will no longer be your light by day,

poetryblock.poem: and the brightness of the moon will not shine on you.
The Lord will be your everlasting light,
and your God will be your splendour.

poem.verse: 20Your sun will no longer set,

poetryblock.poem: and your moon will not fade;
for the Lord will be your everlasting light,
and the days of your sorrow will be over.

poem.verse: 21All your people will be righteous;

poetryblock.poem: they will possess the land for ever;
they are the branch I planted,
the work of my hands,
so that I may be glorified.

poem.verse: 22The least will become a thousand,

poetryblock.poem: the smallest a mighty nation.
I am the Lord;
I will accomplish it quickly in its time.

poem.verse: 1The Spirit of the Lord God is on me,

poetryblock.poem: because the Lord has anointed me
to bring good news to the poor.
He has sent me to heal the broken-hearted,
to proclaim liberty to the captives
and freedom to the prisoners;

poem.verse: 2to proclaim the year of the Lord’s favour,

poetryblock.poem: and the day of our God’s vengeance;
to comfort all who mourn,

poem.verse: 3to provide for those who mourn in Zion;

poetryblock.poem: to give them a crown of beauty instead of ashes,
festive oil instead of mourning,
and splendid clothes instead of despair.
And they will be called righteous trees,
planted by the Lord
to glorify him.

poem.verse: 4They will rebuild the ancient ruins;

poetryblock.poem: they will restore the former devastations;
they will renew the ruined cities,
the devastations of many generations.

poem.verse: 5Strangers will stand and feed your flocks,

poetryblock.poem: and foreigners will be your ploughmen and vinedressers.

poem.verse: 6But you will be called the Lord’s priests;

poetryblock.poem: they will speak of you as ministers of our God;
you will eat the wealth of the nations,
and you will boast in their riches.

poem.verse: 7In place of your shame, you will have a double portion;

poetryblock.poem: in place of disgrace, they will rejoice over their share.
So they will possess double in their land,
and eternal joy will be theirs.

poem.verse: 8For I the Lord love justice;

poetryblock.poem: I hate robbery and injustice;
I will faithfully reward my people
and make a permanent covenant with them.

poem.verse: 9Their descendants will be known among the nations,

poetryblock.poem: and their posterity among the peoples.
All who see them will recognise
that they are a people the Lord has blessed.

poem.verse: 10I rejoice greatly in the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: I exult in my God;
for he has clothed me with the garments of salvation
and wrapped me in a robe of righteousness,
as a groom wears a turban
and as a bride adorns herself with her jewels.

poem.verse: 11For as the earth produces its growth,

poetryblock.poem: and as a garden enables what is sown to spring up,
so the Lord God will cause righteousness and praise
to spring up before all the nations.

poem.verse: 1I will not keep silent because of Zion,

poetryblock.poem: and I will not keep still because of Jerusalem,
until her righteousness shines like a bright light,
and her salvation like a flaming torch.

poem.verse: 2Nations will see your righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: and all kings your glory.
You will be given a new name
that the Lord’s mouth will announce.

poem.verse: 3You will be a glorious crown in the Lord’s hand,

poetryblock.poem: and a royal diadem in the palm of your God’s hand.

poem.verse: 4You will no longer be called Deserted,

poetryblock.poem: and your land will not be called Desolate;
instead, you will be called My Delight Is in Her,
and your land Married;
for the Lord delights in you,
and your land will be married.

poem.verse: 5For as a young man marries a young woman,

poetryblock.poem: so your sons will marry you;
and as a groom rejoices over his bride,
so your God will rejoice over you.

poem.verse: 6Jerusalem,

poetryblock.poem: I have appointed watchmen on your walls;
they will never be silent, day or night.
There is no rest for you,
who remind the Lord.

poem.verse: 7Do not give him rest

poetryblock.poem: until he establishes and makes Jerusalem
the praise of the earth.

poem.verse: 8The Lord has sworn with his right hand

poetryblock.poem: and his strong arm:
I will no longer give your grain
to your enemies for food,
and foreigners will not drink the new wine
for which you have laboured.

poem.verse: 9For those who gather grain will eat it

poetryblock.poem: and praise the Lord,
and those who harvest the grapes will drink the wine
in my holy courts.

poem.verse: 10Go out, go out through the city gates;

poetryblock.poem: prepare a way for the people!
Build it up, build up the road;
clear away the stones!
Raise a banner for the peoples.

poem.verse: 11Look, the Lord has proclaimed

poetryblock.poem: to the ends of the earth,
‘Say to Daughter Zion:
Look, your salvation is coming,
his wages are with him,
and his reward accompanies him.’

poem.verse: 12And they will be called the Holy People,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord’s Redeemed;
and you will be called Cared For,
A City Not Deserted.

poem.verse: 1Who is this coming from Edom

poetryblock.poem: in crimson-stained garments from Bozrah –
this one who is splendid in his apparel,
striding in his formidable might?
It is I, proclaiming vindication,
powerful to save.

poem.verse: 2Why are your clothes red,

poetryblock.poem: and your garments like one who treads a winepress?

poem.verse: 3I trampled the winepress alone,

poetryblock.poem: and no one from the nations was with me.
I trampled them in my anger
and ground them underfoot in my fury;
their blood spattered my garments,
and all my clothes were stained.

poem.verse: 4For I planned the day of vengeance,

poetryblock.poem: and the year of my redemption came.

poem.verse: 5I looked, but there was no one to help,

poetryblock.poem: and I was amazed that no one assisted;
so my arm accomplished victory for me,
and my wrath assisted me.

poem.verse: 6I crushed nations in my anger;

poetryblock.poem: I made them drunk with my wrath
and poured out their blood on the ground.

poem.verse: 7I will make known the Lord’s faithful love

poetryblock.poem: and the Lord’s praiseworthy acts,
because of all the Lord has done for us –
even the many good things
he has done for the house of Israel,
which he did for them based on his compassion
and the abundance of his faithful love.

poem.verse: 8He said, ‘They are indeed my people,

poetryblock.poem: children who will not be disloyal,’
and he became their Saviour.

poem.verse: 9In all their suffering, he suffered,

poetryblock.poem: and the angel of his presence saved them.
He redeemed them
because of his love and compassion;
he lifted them up and carried them
all the days of the past.

poem.verse: 10But they rebelled

poetryblock.poem: and grieved his Holy Spirit.
So he became their enemy
and fought against them.

poem.verse: 11Then he remembered the days of the past,

poetryblock.poem: the days of Moses and his people.
Where is he who brought them out of the sea
with the shepherds of his flock?
Where is he who put his Holy Spirit among the flock?

poem.verse: 12He made his glorious strength

poetryblock.poem: available at the right hand of Moses,
divided the water before them
to make an eternal name for himself,

poem.verse: 13and led them through the depths

poetryblock.poem: like a horse in the wilderness,
so that they did not stumble.

poem.verse: 14Like cattle that go down into the valley,

poetryblock.poem: the Spirit of the Lord gave them rest.
You led your people this way
to make a glorious name for yourself.

poem.verse: 15Look down from heaven and see

poetryblock.poem: from your lofty home ​– ​holy and beautiful.
Where is your zeal and your might?
Your yearning and your compassion
are withheld from me.

poem.verse: 16Yet you are our Father,

poetryblock.poem: even though Abraham does not know us
and Israel doesn’t recognise us.
You, Lord, are our Father;
your name is Our Redeemer
from Ancient Times.

poem.verse: 17Why, Lord, do you make us stray from your ways?

poetryblock.poem: You harden our hearts so that we do not fear you.
Return, because of your servants,
the tribes of your heritage.

poem.verse: 18Your holy people had a possession

poetryblock.poem: for a little while,
but our enemies have trampled down
your sanctuary.

poem.verse: 19We have become like those you never ruled,

poetryblock.poem: like those who did not bear your name.

poem.verse: 1If only you would tear the heavens open

poetryblock.poem: and come down,
so that mountains would quake at your presence –

poem.verse: 2just as fire kindles brushwood,

poetryblock.poem: and fire boils water –
to make your name known to your enemies,
so that nations would tremble at your presence!

poem.verse: 3When you did awesome works

poetryblock.poem: that we did not expect,
you came down,
and the mountains quaked at your presence.

poem.verse: 4From ancient times no one has heard,

poetryblock.poem: no one has listened to,
no eye has seen any God except you
who acts on behalf of the one who waits for him.

poem.verse: 5You welcome the one who joyfully does what is right;

poetryblock.poem: they remember you in your ways.
But we have sinned, and you were angry.
How can we be saved if we remain in our sins?

poem.verse: 6All of us have become like something unclean,

poetryblock.poem: and all our righteous acts are like a polluted garment;
all of us wither like a leaf,
and our iniquities carry us away like the wind.

poem.verse: 7No one calls on your name,

poetryblock.poem: striving to take hold of you.
For you have hidden your face from us
and made us melt because of our iniquity.

poem.verse: 8Yet Lord, you are our Father;

poetryblock.poem: we are the clay, and you are our potter;
we all are the work of your hands.

poem.verse: 9Lord, do not be terribly angry

poetryblock.poem: or remember our iniquity for ever.
Please look ​– ​all of us are your people!

poem.verse: 10Your holy cities have become a wilderness;

poetryblock.poem: Zion has become a wilderness,
Jerusalem a desolation.

poem.verse: 11Our holy and beautiful temple,

poetryblock.poem: where our ancestors praised you,
has been burned down,
and all that was dear to us lies in ruins.

poem.verse: 12Lord, after all this, will you restrain yourself?

poetryblock.poem: Will you keep silent and afflict us severely?

poem.verse: 1‘I was sought by those who did not ask;

poetryblock.poem: I was found by those who did not seek me.
I said, “Here I am, here I am,”
to a nation that did not call on my name.

poem.verse: 2I spread out my hands all day long

poetryblock.poem: to a rebellious people
who walk in the path that is not good,
following their own thoughts.

poem.verse: 3These people continually anger me

poetryblock.poem: to my face,
sacrificing in gardens,
burning incense on bricks,

poem.verse: 4sitting among the graves,

poetryblock.poem: spending nights in secret places,
eating the meat of pigs,
and putting polluted broth in their bowls.

poem.verse: 5They say, “Keep to yourself,

poetryblock.poem: don’t come near me, for I am too holy for you! ”
These practices are smoke in my nostrils,
a fire that burns all day long.

poem.verse: 6Look, it is written in front of me:

poetryblock.poem: I will not keep silent, but I will repay;
I will repay them fully

poem.verse: 7for your iniquities and the iniquities

poetryblock.poem: of your ancestors together,’
says the Lord.
‘Because they burned incense on the mountains
and reproached me on the hills,
I will reward them fully
for their former deeds.’

p.verse: 8The Lord says this:

poetryblock.poem: ‘As the new wine is found in a bunch of grapes,
and one says, “Don’t destroy it,
for there’s some good in it,”
so I will act because of my servants
and not destroy them all.

poem.verse: 9I will produce descendants from Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: and heirs to my mountains from Judah;
my chosen ones will possess it,
and my servants will dwell there.

poem.verse: 10Sharon will be a pasture for flocks,

poetryblock.poem: and the Valley of Achor a place for herds to lie down,
for my people who have sought me.

poem.verse: 11But you who abandon the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: who forget my holy mountain,
who prepare a table for Fortune
and fill bowls of mixed wine for Destiny,

poem.verse: 12I will destine you for the sword,

poetryblock.poem: and all of you will kneel down to be slaughtered,
because I called and you did not answer,
I spoke and you did not hear;
you did what was evil in my sight
and chose what I did not delight in.’

p.verse: 13Therefore, this is what the Lord God says:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Look! My servants will eat,
but you will be hungry.
Look! My servants will drink,
but you will be thirsty.
Look! My servants will rejoice,
but you will be put to shame.

poem.verse: 14Look! My servants will shout for joy from a glad heart,

poetryblock.poem: but you will cry out from an anguished heart,
and you will lament out of a broken spirit.

poem.verse: 15You will leave your name behind

poetryblock.poem: as a curse for my chosen ones,
and the Lord God will kill you;
but he will give his servants another name.

poem.verse: 16Whoever asks for a blessing in the land

poetryblock.poem: will ask for a blessing by the God of truth,
and whoever swears in the land
will swear by the God of truth.
For the former troubles will be forgotten
and hidden from my sight.

poem.verse: 17‘For I will create new heavens and a new earth;

poetryblock.poem: the past events will not be remembered or come to mind.

poem.verse: 18Then be glad and rejoice for ever

poetryblock.poem: in what I am creating;
for I will create Jerusalem to be a joy
and its people to be a delight.

poem.verse: 19I will rejoice in Jerusalem

poetryblock.poem: and be glad in my people.
The sound of weeping and crying
will no longer be heard in her.

poem.verse: 20In her, a nursing infant will no longer live

poetryblock.poem: only a few days,
or an old man not live out his days.
Indeed, the one who dies at a hundred years old
will be mourned as a young man,
and the one who misses a hundred years
will be considered cursed.

poem.verse: 21People will build houses and live in them;

poetryblock.poem: they will plant vineyards and eat their fruit.

poem.verse: 22They will not build and others live in them;

poetryblock.poem: they will not plant and others eat.
For my people’s lives will be
like the lifetime of a tree.
My chosen ones will fully enjoy
the work of their hands.

poem.verse: 23They will not labour without success

poetryblock.poem: or bear children destined for disaster,
for they will be a people blessed by the Lord
along with their descendants.

poem.verse: 24Even before they call, I will answer;

poetryblock.poem: while they are still speaking, I will hear.

poem.verse: 25The wolf and the lamb will feed together,

poetryblock.poem: and the lion will eat straw like cattle,
but the serpent’s food will be dust!
They will not do what is evil or destroy
on my entire holy mountain,’
says the Lord.

p.verse: 1This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Heaven is my throne,
and earth is my footstool.
Where could you possibly build a house for me?
And where would my resting place be?

poem.verse: 2My hand made all these things,

poetryblock.poem: and so they all came into being.
This is the Lord’s declaration.
I will look favourably on this kind of person:
one who is humble, submissive in spirit,
and trembles at my word.

poem.verse: 3One person slaughters an ox, another kills a person;

poetryblock.poem: one person sacrifices a lamb, another breaks a dog’s neck;
one person offers a grain offering, another offers pig’s blood;
one person offers incense, another praises an idol –
all these have chosen their ways
and delight in their abhorrent practices.

poem.verse: 4So I will choose their punishment,

poetryblock.poem: and I will bring on them what they dread
because I called and no one answered;
I spoke and they did not listen;
they did what was evil in my sight
and chose what I did not delight in.

poem.verse: 5You who tremble at his word,

poetryblock.poem: hear the word of the Lord:
‘Your brothers who hate and exclude you
for my name’s sake have said,
“Let the Lord be glorified
so that we can see your joy! ”
But they will be put to shame.’

poem.verse: 6A sound of uproar from the city!

poetryblock.poem: A voice from the temple –
the voice of the Lord,
paying back his enemies what they deserve!

poem.verse: 7Before Zion was in labour, she gave birth;

poetryblock.poem: before she was in pain, she delivered a boy.

poem.verse: 8Who has heard of such a thing?

poetryblock.poem: Who has seen such things?
Can a land be born in one day
or a nation be delivered in an instant?
Yet as soon as Zion was in labour,
she gave birth to her sons.

poem.verse: 9‘Will I bring a baby to the point of birth

poetryblock.poem: and not deliver it? ’
says the Lord;
‘or will I who deliver, close the womb? ’
says your God.

poem.verse: 10Be glad for Jerusalem and rejoice over her,

poetryblock.poem: all who love her.
Rejoice greatly with her,
all who mourn over her –

poem.verse: 11so that you may nurse and be satisfied

poetryblock.poem: from her comforting breast
and drink deeply and delight yourselves
from her glorious breasts.

p.verse: 12For this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will make peace flow to her like a river,
and the wealth of nations like a flood;
you will nurse and be carried on her hip
and bounced on her lap.

poem.verse: 13As a mother comforts her son,

poetryblock.poem: so I will comfort you,
and you will be comforted in Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 14You will see, you will rejoice,

poetryblock.poem: and you will flourish like grass;
then the Lord’s power will be revealed to his servants,
but he will show his wrath against his enemies.

poem.verse: 15Look, the Lord will come with fire –

poetryblock.poem: his chariots are like the whirlwind –
to execute his anger with fury
and his rebuke with flames of fire.

poem.verse: 16For the Lord will execute judgement

poetryblock.poem: on all humanity with his fiery sword,
and many will be slain by the Lord.

p.verse: 17‘Those who dedicate and purify themselves to enter the groves following their leader, eating meat from pigs, vermin, and rats, will perish together.’
18‘Knowing their works and their thoughts, I have come to gather all nations and languages; they will come and see my glory.

19I will establish a sign among them, and I will send survivors from them to the nations ​– ​to Tarshish, Put, Lud (who are archers), Tubal, Javan, and the coasts and islands far away ​– ​who have not heard about me or seen my glory. And they will proclaim my glory among the nations.

20They will bring all your brothers from all the nations as a gift to the Lord on horses and chariots, in litters, and on mules and camels, to my holy mountain Jerusalem,’ says the Lord, ‘just as the Israelites bring an offering in a clean vessel to the house of the Lord.
21I will also take some of them as priests and Levites,’ says the Lord.

poem.verse: 22‘For just as the new heavens and the new earth,

poetryblock.poem: which I will make,
will remain before me’ –
this is the Lord’s declaration –
‘so your offspring and your name will remain.

poem.verse: 23All humanity will come to worship me

poetryblock.poem: from one New Moon to another
and from one Sabbath to another,’
says the Lord.

p.verse: 24‘As they leave, they will see the dead bodies of those who have rebelled against me; for their worm will never die, their fire will never go out, and they will be a horror to all humanity.’
